—Can the Minister for Trade advise the Senate of the outcome of a review by the GATT of Australia's trade and economic policies which, according to media reports, has delivered a favourable assessment of the policies that this government has pursued? Does the minister think that this means the GATT believes that the government's policies are the right ones? Should Australians be concerned at the reports that Australian tariff policies and the use of anti-dumping were criticised by some of our trading partners?

—On 3 and 4 February the GATT council conducted a review under the trade policy review mechanism of Australia's trade and economic policies. The council overwhelmingly praised those policies: it found that the government's reforms have worked to address the economic fundamentals and have fundamentally enhanced Australia's productivity and competitiveness. In fact, various participants described Australia's record as `a model for other countries' and `exemplary'.

PARA.TAB: In all, the assessment by GATT represents not only a recognition of our progress in economic reform but also a fundamental endorsement of our overall approach. In practical terms, the reforms initiated and carried out by the government, and perceived accurately by our trading partners and other members of the GATT, have put us in a very good position to reap the benefits arising out of the success of the Uruguay Round—the success to which my predecessor, Senator Cook, and his predecessors made such an outstanding contribution.

That GATT round has provided Australia with enormous opportunities. It is now up to Australia to be good enough to take advantage of those opportunities. This GATT policy review endorses, quite correctly, the view that the policies of the government in trade reform, in industry and in other areas have left us very well placed to take advantage of those ample opportunities which will make a significant contribution to our economy. They provide a very solid platform on which to establish our economic and trading future.

That is not to say there were no criticisms at the margin. Overwhelmingly, it was a very positive review and everybody said so, but there were criticisms at the margin. It is never a sensible policy to close one's ears to criticism, particularly when that criticism comes from trading partners and friends. I think Australia's representatives effectively rebutted the criticisms; nevertheless it is wise that we consider them.

In particular, a number of countries raised concerns about the frequency with which anti-dumping and countervailing actions are taken in Australia. In fact, rather than being lax in the application of measures against dumped or subsidised imports, as we get criticised for from time to time in the Senate, we were seen internationally as being too vigorous in the pursuit of anti-dumping and countervailing actions. That, of course, is not the government's view—we think our laws and practices are consistent with the international rules; they are fully transparent. We do not use them as non-tariff barriers to address these sorts of issues, and they are only used when dumping or subsidisation and damage are proven.

Overall, we do not accept the criticism: we think our trade policies are more open and transparent and leave us better placed for taking advantage of the GATT opportunities than the criticisms put to us by the critics. The critics of the policies would do well perhaps to have policies as open and effective as ours. But, overall, this report is overwhelmingly positive and constructive: it gives deserved recognition to the reforms which we have undertaken, and it leaves us well positioned to take full advantage of the opportunities provided by the successful negotiation of the GATT round.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Trade. PARA.TAB: What is gratifying is not simply that the GATT endorsed the policy framework of the government, but that it recognised the fact that that framework has left us well placed to take advantage of the enormous trade and, therefore, job benefits that can flow from the successful negotiation of GATT. TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and it relates to human rights. The weekend mortar attack on the main Sarajevo market has been universally condemned as an outrage. Does not the international community now have the moral responsibility to act firmly to end such atrocities and at least to make good the threats to conduct air strikes to protect the legions of unarmed civilians who are the daily victims of this appalling conflict?

—The mortar attack on the Sarajevo market, where more than 60 people died and more than 200 people were wounded, some very seriously, was, on any view, a despicable and barbaric act. It was not the first of its kind in this awful conflict, but it was certainly one of the worst single incidents of the war. As I said to the ABC yesterday, and I cannot put it personally any more strongly, it seems to me that there is a special place in hell for those who bomb innocent children in playgrounds or women and children and other innocent civilians going about their business in the marketplaces of cities.

PARA.TAB: The responsibility for this particular attack has not yet been able to be definitively attributed and, indeed, it may never be able to be definitively attributed. But I think it is fair to say that the working assumption of the international community is that the responsibility most likely does lie with the artillery of the Bosnian Serbs, who have certainly been responsible for many similar attacks in the past.

The question is: what can—should—the international community be doing about it? Certainly, the case for air strikes is becoming more compelling and more irresistible. It was reported this morning that the Secretary-General of the UN has written to NATO Secretary-General Woerner requesting that authorisation be given for air strikes on targets around Sarajevo. That does not necessarily mean they will follow immediately, but the processes of creating the conditions for them have certainly been gone through.

There is a continuing hesitation, however, among members of the international community about the use of such strikes, their effectiveness and their possible implications. I have to say that I find that understandable. The Australian government has certainly not been as critical about that hesitation as some people have urged us to be. The problem is essentially twofold. Firstly, there is the likely immediate effectiveness of the strikes in dealing just with the immediate problem—in this instance, mortar attacks from the surrounding hillsides. Mortars are extremely mobile pieces of equipment. The nature of the terrain is such that it cannot be assumed that even the most technically effective and efficient air strikes will be successful in removing that particular threat.

Secondly, and in many ways more importantly, there are very real questions about the impact of strikes, successful or otherwise, on the humanitarian operations that are proceeding in Bosnia and whether or not the net result would be to possibly increase the level of suffering. That issue arises because there have been threats in the past, and they have been very real, of retaliation against UN forces in a circumstance where, under cover of the UN resolution, such strikes were launched. There is an immediate question about the implications of that for the 11,500 UNPROFOR troops that are in Bosnia at the moment. There is a serious question concerning their capacity, under such assault, to continue to give protection to the humanitarian convoys and relief operations that are presently under way—it being recalled that there are over 2.3 million people in Bosnia now daily receiving humanitarian assistance of one kind or another from these agencies.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Australian government have a position?

—Senator Hill can continue to interject, as he is now, asking what the government's position is. The government's position is that it is an extremely difficult problem in which the arguments are very finely balanced. Australia is not a party to the immediate decision-making process; we do not have people on the ground and I am not going to posture and pontificate about what should be done in this situation when the matters are as finely balanced as they are.

PARA.TAB: It is a matter for very fine judgment by those who have responsibility for the humanitarian operations. It is a matter for very fine judgment by those who have their own citizens at risk. It is a matter for very fine judgment by everyone who has the best interests of the Bosnian people deeply at heart in the context of this particular decision. I am saying that we in Australia will support any decision that is made as a result of these proper processes working themselves out. But I am not going to pontificate in the way that I am being invited to do about this very difficult and delicate issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Further to that answer, and on the problem of identifying the people responsible for these barbarities, are there impediments to equipping UNPROFOR with state-of-the-art technology which is available to NATO member countries, to identify the sources of such attacks so that the international community can at least make a clear judgment about the source of such cowardly acts?

—I am not aware of any policy or technical impediment to the provision of UNPROFOR with such equipment. It is the case, I am advised, that experts can often determine from where a shell or mortar has been fired by analysing the crater. There is also mortar locating radar equipment which enables an estimate of location of the source of firing. If the latter equipment is not available to UNPROFOR at this time, there is certainly a case for its provision so that the perpetrators of such acts can be better known than they seem to be at the moment.

PARA.TAB: The difficulty about even a force equipped with such material, however, is that mortars, as I have said, are highly mobile pieces of equipment, which always complicates their identification. In the particular situation of the marketplace over the weekend, I have seen reports quoting Lieutenant-General Rose, the UN military commander in Bosnia, as saying that crater analysis has been completed of that shell, but that it was impossible to tell the precise location from which it came and, as a result, who fired it.

ANSWER.PARA: NEW ECONOMICS FOUNDATION REPORT ON ENVIRONMENTAL PERFORMANCES IN OECD COUNTRIES
Question to be asked by Senator Margetts:

I refer the Minister to recent media reports relating to the release of a survey by the New Economics Foundation in London which found that Australia ranked very poorly in an analysis of key environmental issues and ask:
1.What action is the Australian Government taking to address the fact that Australian households produce the world's highest per capita level of household garbage?
2.What action is the Australian Government taking to reduce the high level of carbon dioxide and sulphur dioxide emissions in this country?
3.What action is the Australian Government taking to redress the low level of funding generally for environment protection in this country compared to other OECD countries?

Before answering the three specific questions asked by Senator Margetts, I would like to comment on the New Economics Foundation Report that is the basis for her question. Quite simply, the report is so flawed in its methodology that it is misleading in the extreme to rank any one country against other OECD members in the form of a league table. It is not valid to reach conclusions in an overall sense from such an analysis. The report itself contains quite important qualifications on this issue. For example it says, and I quote
."While mindful of some valid problems in interpreting the data. . . . . . "
AND
."This was a relatively quick and dirty exercise"
AND
."The 11 indicators (on which the scoring was based) represent a relatively ad hoc selection of potential indicators."

I could go on. Suffice it to say that the report gathers together data for 11 indicators to produce a score for each country against each indicator. Such an approach is flawed, with no weighting being given to the importance of individual indicators, no real rigour in the selection of the 11 indicators in the first place and an acknowledgment that the OECD figures on which the indicators are based are themselves heavily qualified, due to the virtual impossibility of obtaining comparable figures based on standard definitions for the 24 OECD countries.
I should also add that OECD itself is very critical of the methodology used in the article, describing it as "highly misleading".
I now address each of Senator Margetts' questions:
1.What action is the Australian Government taking to address the fact that Australian households produce the world's highest per capita level of household garbage?
.I am aware of the survey and have seen the report which uses a dubious methodology to compare the environmental performance of 21 OECD countries.

.Firstly, let me say that I dispute the so called fact that Australian households produce the most garbage in the world. If you look at the report—and it is clearly acknowledged by the authors—there are some serious limitations to compiling and comparing data on waste generation from different countries. This because the approaches to the surveying and definition of waste varies considerably. For example, the report states that "some definitions include household waste others include commercial activities, office buildings, institutions such as schools and government buildings".
.Secondly, the report quotes Australian data which is more than 5 years old. This ignores many of the significant initiatives which have been undertaken during that period including:

PARA.TAB: -development of a number of strategies to address waste minimisation, recycling, packaging, and oil and tyres;
-economic studies of waste generation and disposal;
-development of a National Waste Database;
-supporting local government to manage waste more effectively through the provision of information and funding of innovative waste minimisation projects.

ANSWER.PARA: 2.What action is the Australian Government taking to reduce the high level of carbon dioxide and sulphur dioxide emissions in this country?
Carbon Dioxide

The Australian Government, along with all State and Territory Governments adopted the first phase of the National Greenhouse Gas Strategy in 1992. The Strategy give particular attention to implementing measures in the energy production, distribution and use sectors where the greatest impact on carbon dioxide emissions can be expected. Australia has already submitted the National Greenhouse Response Strategy to the international community involved in negotiations on the Climate Change Convention as the means by which Australia will meet many of our obligations under the Convention. Implementation of the first phase of the Strategy is already well underway.
Sulphur Dioxide

Australia's indigenous fossil fuels are low in sulphur and energy use is not a significant source of sulphur oxide emissions. Our sulphur emissions are derived mainly from smelting of non-ferrous metals such as lead and gold.

The main environmental impacts of sulphur oxides emissions is the formation of acid deposition or acid rain. The ESD Report on Energy Use stated that `the evidence to date indicates that acid rain is not a national problem for Australia'. The reasons identified in the ESD report include that we have a relatively low concentration fo industrial development, absence of heavily industrialised neighbouring countries and the fact that Australia is endowed with a number of soils having a moderate to good capacity to neutralise acid rain.

Sulphur oxides do cause local problems (health and material and plant damage) but in Australia they are confined to mining towns such as Mt Isa and Kalgoorlie, but actions are being undertaken to reduce such impacts.

Whilst the control of emission levels is essentially a matter for the States, the Commonwealth is coordinating an appraisal of the national air quality goal for sulphur dioxide. The discussion paper recently completed by the National Health and Medical Research Council recommends that Australia's current sulphur dioxide air quality goal is adequate and should be re-endorsed.
3.What action is the Australian Government taking to redress the low level of funding generally for environment protection in this country compared to other OECD countries?

I assume that this question arises as a result of the recently published (25 January 1994) report by the Australian Bureau of Statistics. Again, before commenting in detail, a few points should be made.

PARA.TAB: -only 10 countries were included in the comparison. 14 were omitted. The 10 included were Australia, Canada, US, Japan, Austria, France, Germany, Netherlands, Portugal and UK.
-the comparisons should be regarded an indicative only, due to reporting difficulties in obtaining comparable data for environmental expenditure from government and industry sectors.

—I address my question to the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel. The minister will be very aware of the special demands placed on service families, especially the requirement for mobility. Will he be undertaking any special planning for further measures to assist service families as a special focus during the International Year of the Family?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: DEFENCE SCIENCE AND PERSONNEL; VETERANS' AFFAIRS

TALK.START.PARA: —Over recent years the government and the ADF have been increasingly sensitive to the special demands placed on service families, and the support provided to them has grown substantially. Existing family support services cover a wide and varied field, from providing counselling to organising social functions, establishing defence information networks, setting up a family support funding program—which, of course, is to sponsor family oriented projects—operating the defence home owner loan scheme and building and maintaining child-care centres. I believe we have led the community with some of these programs but, as always, there is scope for continuing improvement.

PARA.TAB: I am pleased with the enthusiasm with which the ADF has seized the opportunity in this year's International Year of the Family to formulate a series of initiatives which will, I think, fill the gaps and supplement and improve the existing services. In fact, Professor Bettina Cass, who is chair of the National Council for the International Year of the Family, believes that the ADF is taking a leading role in supporting the specific needs of the families of its serving members. In general, the feedback that I have had is that Defence has much to be proud of and that the program put together for the ADF for the IYF is a model that others would do well to follow.

I launched Defence's contribution to the IYF in Townsville on Friday when I officially opened the Coral Sea Early Childhood Centre. I know Senator Reynolds knows that centre well. That is Defence's ninth employer-sponsored child-care centre. I think it was an appropriate venue for the IYF launch because Defence is one of the leading providers of employer-sponsored child care in Australia.

A number of the initiatives that have been announced for IYF include a number of family skills training courses, which are to be developed and offered to families through their community development officers, to provide counselling services where they are needed. The training courses will cover marriage preparation, communicating and load sharing, budgeting and financial planning, use of alcohol, conflict resolution and the like.

A conference on families in the Defence Force will be held at the Australian Defence Studies Centre on 25 February 1994 to discuss the support provided to service families and highlight the need for improvements. The ADF will continue to support initiatives for a national curriculum and school starting age, which are important for the children of Defence Force families and which will minimise the impact of changed postings on children's education.

I also want to mention in the time available to me the family medical passport which will be introduced so that a family's health will not be jeopardised when it moves posting. Records are now held, as honourable senators know, with civilian practitioners. This passport will allow an ADF family to take with it an important medical record of that family as and when it is posted.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Will discussions between the Australian government and Mr Paias Wingti include human rights as a high priority and, in particular, will discussions include the situation on Bougainville and visits by representatives of independent organisations to all parts of that island to assess conditions there and possible solutions?

—Honourable senators will be aware that the Papua New Guinea Prime Minister, Mr Paias Wingti, will be visiting Australia from tomorrow until 14 February as a guest of the Australian government. During his visit Prime Minister Wingti will meet our Prime Minister and other ministers in Canberra. He will also have meetings with the state governments of Victoria, New South Wales and Queensland, and with business leaders in those states.

PARA.TAB: We attach very high priority to relations with Papua New Guinea. We have shared interests in a large number of areas, including engagement in Asia, and more recently in the development of APEC with PNG as a member. Bougainville and human rights generally will be important issues for discussion with Prime Minister Wingti. We will certainly be urging, as we have from the outset, the Wingti government to seek a peaceful resolution of the Bougainville crisis through the process of reconciliation among all parties to the conflict. In that context, we will be reiterating our willingness to assist by facilitating a meeting of Bougainvillean leaders, perhaps by providing a venue or some other form of logistical support, provided that all parties to the conflict agree that our involvement would be helpful.

As we have said on a number of occasions, we will also give further consideration to any proposals for further assistance by way of relief and rehabilitation in support of the PNG government's own efforts on Bougainville. We will also again take the opportunity to raise the issue of human rights, particularly on Bougainville, making clear our abhorrence of human rights violations perpetrated by whichever side.

In relation to the question of whether there should be—as the honourable senator suggested—visits by representatives of independent organisations to various parts of the province to assess conditions there, and possible solutions, might I say that that is an issue for the Papua New Guinea government itself to determine. TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Health. How long will it be before Australians affected by, or who have, osteoporosis will be able to claim a rebate for the important diagnostic test of densitometry?

—As I am sure Senator Reid knows, we have been seeking expert advice on specification and implementation of Medicare benefits for bone densitometry for some time. In fact, the Medicare Benefits Advisory Committee met last year on a number of occasions to discuss this issue. As is normally the case for health ministers—I do not believe that has any political colour—I have accepted all of the committee's recommendations on the provision of Medicare benefits for certain bone densitometry tests, including a series of measures to promote quality and appropriate use of the technology.

PARA.TAB: The necessary determination under the Health Insurance Act is scheduled to go to the executive council at the first available opportunity—and I think that is later this week. It is intended that Medicare benefits be made available from 1 March for bone densitometry in line with the Medicare Benefits Advisory Committee's recommendations. The schedule fee will be $75 per service. There will be ongoing monitoring of what Medicare usage there is of this service over the course of the next 12 months. To accompany the introduction there will be an information package targeting the medical profession and the public, and hopefully that will be provided simultaneously. The implementation of these measures gives effect to the government's 1993 federal election commitment and subsequent 1993-94 budget commitment to introduce Medicare benefits for bone densitometry testing. The estimated financial implications of this are $1.2 million in 1993-94 and $3.6 million in 1994-95, rising annually thereafter depending on the number of repeat scans.

The advisory committee recommended that the payment of benefits should be confined to two clinical applications, based on a review of current scientific knowledge and clinical practice. These are, firstly, in the confirmation and monitoring of established osteoporosis and, secondly, in the diagnosis and monitoring of bone loss associated with a specific set of clinical conditions. These include chronic liver disease, chronic renal disease, rheumatoid arthritis and proven malabsorptive disorders.

On the issue of the use of bone densitometry as a screening tool to detect developing osteoporosis amongst menopausal women, the advisory committee concluded that there was insufficient scientific evidence to warrant the payment of Medicare benefits for this service. I intend to continue to look at that, but that is certainly the state of advice as it currently stands. Safeguards on usage include referral by a medical practitioner, one service only every 24 months and tests on only two types of machines, that is, dual x-ray absorptiometry and quantitative computerised tomography.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy inform the Senate of the contribution that the rural and resources sectors are likely to play in the economic recovery? In particular, can the minister comment on the assessment of the rural and resources sectors made during last week's National Agricultural and Resource Outlook Conference?

—The general outlook at last week's National Agricultural and Resource Outlook Conference hosted by ABARE was one of cautious optimism for Australia's primary industry and resource industries. Both of those sectors of our economy are set to contribute very strongly to the improvement in the Australian economy which is now under way. The sector will benefit particularly from the strengthening of the world economy over the remainder of the 1990s, as the benefit of the successful conclusion of the GATT round and its progressive implementation between 1995 and 2000 become apparent.

PARA.TAB: ABARE predicts that commodity prices are set to rise. I might add that this is in stark contrast to the interpretation that Senator Crane placed on this matter last week. Those predictions are that commodity prices are set to rise in 1994-95 from their current low points. Specifically, prices are expected to rise by seven per cent in 1994-95 and to continue to rise through 1996-97. Australia's economic performance is closely tied to its trade performance and the trade performance of these sectors.

These commodity price rises will feed into improved trade figures for Australia. Rural export earnings are forecast to rise by 12 per cent in real terms between 1993-94 and 1998-99 and mineral resource earnings are expected to rise by 21 per cent in real terms over the same period. Again, as a result mainly of better prices, farm financial conditions are expected to improve markedly with big improvements in farm cash income, especially in the broad acre and dairy sectors of primary industry. This will provide opportunities for farmers to reduce debt and increase their investment.

The government's policies will be aimed at ensuring that commodity industries continue to have a positive future by working for continued world trade liberalisation, ensuring Australia builds on our recent export push into Asia and increasing economic efficiency through continued pressure on microeconomic reform.

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) to a question without notice asked by Senator Michael Baume this day, relating to the Prime Minister's investment in a piggery.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Gareth Evans, in response to my questions about the extent of the obligation of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) to unnamed people for an unnamed amount, even though these were described by Mr Constantinidis, his partner, as pretty serious extra commitments, indicated that we and the public of Australia had no right to inquire about such matters; that it was not our business. He went on to say that it would be a proper interest of the Australian people only if the Prime Minister were involved in personal exertion on behalf of those companies, or if there was a conflict of interest.

PARA.TAB: It is exactly on those grounds that it is a matter of public concern. There are several key questions. Has the Prime Minister, either wittingly or unwittingly, used his position as Prime Minister, or Treasurer at some stage, to bring himself commercial benefit? It is a reasonable question. Has his half ownership of his piggery group brought him any benefits because he has had—and still holds—such significant offices? Did his half ownership—and these are proper questions that emerge from this matter—of the piggery group encourage, for example, the Danes to finally do the deal with Brown and Hatton that they had not, they say, done until he became involved with the Brown and Hatton group?

Other people are wondering how the Prime Minister managed to avoid the personal guarantees and personal commitments—which its former owners had to front up with—for the $20 million-odd loans to his piggery groups from the Commonwealth Bank of Australia.

There is a potential for his role as Prime Minister to bring a commercial benefit. That is why it is vital that everything be seen to be above board and be placed on the record. That is why, over a period of something like two years, I have sought to have the facts placed on the record. It was only as a result of my questioning that any accurate information whatsoever on this matter has come forward.

The first statements we saw in this matter revealed that the Prime Minister had a $43,000 interest in this venture instead of a $430,000 interest. Nothing was done to correct that false impression or the false impressions created by false and misleading reports to the Australian Securities Commission. Senator Evans seeks consistently to brush all this aside by saying, `This is muckraking—unsubstantiated muckraking'. These are the facts which have never been denied and which Senator Evans cannot deny. The screen of muck that the minister is spreading around is simply unsustainable and a disgrace.

The huge indebtedness of the Prime Minister's companies represents an unprecedented obligation on any Prime Minister of Australia. It is not necessarily a legal and direct obligation because there is the corporate veil put between the Prime Minister and this massive $30 million obligation. To what extent does this create the potential for a conflict of interest, not even suggesting that the Prime Minister might wittingly be involved in it?

If various people in this community took the view that the Prime Minister had very serious financial obligations and something should be done to make certain that he was not carrying the burden of them, there would be potential for conflict. That would create a potential for conflict, a potential for people to come to the aid of the Prime Minister because of his massive, unprecedented, ultimate obligation. Remember this, the Prime Minister will get the benefit of those huge loans but he is not facing the obligation of those huge loans because of the corporate veil.

The people of Australia have a right to know to what extent their Prime Minister is in hock—moral hock and indirect hock. This government has done everything it can to prevent that information being provided to the people of Australia. They deserve to know, they should know and they must know.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not feel under a special obligation to respond on every occasion that Senator Baume rises to his feet. I guess this is going to be an ongoing saga through the course of this year as it was, as he says, for most of the last two years. I simply remind him and I remind the Senate that every time he has got to his feet in the past in order to raise these questions in a most portentous fashion in the public interest he has raised issue after issue. To the extent that those issues have any sort of substance requiring any response at all, Senator Baume has fallen flat on his face every time.

He raised questions about alleged influence in relation to the Foreign Investment Review Board process, again in a pompous and portentous way, saying that he was doing it in the public interest. He was absolutely wrong and foolishly wrong when the matter was fully explained. He has raised questions in the context of litigation now pending in New South Wales about alleged conflicts of interest so far as tax benefits are concerned. He is wrong, wrong, wrong. He raised factual questions about the nature and extent of the Prime Minister's investment and he was wrong as soon as the response was put on the public record in relation to that.

As to the $20 million or $22 million loan, Senator Baume ought to be well aware that that is well and truly weighed off against commensurate assets and realisable assets, as I understand it, of the company. It is worth reminding those opposite on this occasion, as we have on previous ones, just how the New South Wales government regards this particular project and its potential expansion. I will quote, for example, from Mr Greiner in 1992 when he was announcing the likely increase in the scale of this project with all the supporting loans that are necessary to produce that result. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Securing of this project now places New South Wales at the forefront of technology in the pig meat industry, increasing our productivity and international competitiveness.

The teaming of leading edge Danish technology with the competitive advantages enjoyed by Brown and Hatton provides the joint venture company Danpork Australia with strong capabilities to supply not only the growing domestic market but also the burgeoning demand for high quality pig meat in the Asian region.
This undertaking is not only large; it is of major strategic significance to New South Wales. My government will continue to give top priority to fast tracking the project—
he has not quite done that—
through the necessary environmental assessment and approvals processes so that the economic benefits of this significant development are realised as quickly as possible.

Mr Armstrong, the Deputy Premier of New South Wales and Minister for Agriculture and Rural Affairs, said at the same time the project would underpin the future of the state's pig industry and give an enormous boost to grain and fodder producers.

PARA.TAB: This is the nature of the enterprise in which the Prime Minister, with the best will in the world, is engaged, to make his contribution to the economic health of this particular industry, to his own state and to the nation. In doing so, he is taking some commercial risks, as entrepreneurs and shareholders always do with a significant equity investment. But he does not need to be or deserve to be, nor is he justified in being, exposed to the kind of questioning that those opposite are going in with day in day out utterly without substance, as has been demonstrated in the way in which they have fallen flat on their faces on all those previous occasions when they have tried to get it going.

These are matters of commercial judgment on the part of the Prime Minister, on the part of the reputable banks and other companies that are engaging in it. Those opposite have not come up with a skerrick of a suggestion that there is any impropriety, any breach of the familiar principles that govern ministerial responsibility or prime ministerial responsibility in these matters. They are just muckraking and crawling around the bottom of the barrel, as they have been for the last couple of years. They will get nowhere. Why do they not abandon the unequal struggle?

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Trade (Senator McMullan) to a question without notice asked by Senator Spindler this day, relating to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.

SPEECH.PARA: We must be pleased with at least one part of the answer of the Minister for Trade (Senator McMullan) in that he said quite categorically that the government would not relax quarantine and sanitary requirements, even though they are being claimed as barriers against imports of agricultural products by some of the member nations of GATT. However, I was less than pleased with another part of his answer to my question on anti-dumping actions by Australia, which are claimed to be at a high level. He did not argue that they would be or should be reduced, nor did he suggest in answer to my request earlier that they should be strengthened.

PARA.TAB: I think the minister should take note that anti-dumping actions taken by Australian companies take up to 12 months, and some take longer; whereas in the United States, because the procedures are much more streamlined than ours, they can take days. Countervailing tariffs can be introduced within five days.

It is all to do with the onus of proof. We require our companies and industries to prove—and it is sometimes extremely difficult to do so—firstly, that there is damage; secondly, that the damage is directly related to this particular anti-dumping action; and, thirdly, that the anti-dumping action is related to the cost of production in the other country. Clearly it is not in the interest of that country or of the industries located in that country to agree to it. Our industries are certainly prevented from taking effective action. It might be an indication to the minister of the degree of desperation that our industries are facing that, nevertheless, there are so many anti-dumping actions attempted.

The other area that the minister did not address satisfactorily was the request by the other nations to cut tariffs even faster on TCF products and on passenger cars—I had also included telecommunication products, but that is incorrect. In those two areas—TCF and passenger cars, particularly the latter—the minister seemed to be saying that the Mitsubishi $500 million plan of expansion is directly related to Mitsubishi having confidence in and being able to live with the government's car industry plan and with the progressive reduction in tariffs, which will be 15 per cent by the year 2000.

Not all car firms in Australia share either that confidence that this program of reductions will be adhered to or the belief that they can live with it. But let us assume for the moment that Mitsubishi has made the decision that it can do so. The question to the minister was—and he did not answer it—whether the Australian government would take note of the requests made by some of the member states of GATT on the GATT council and in comments on the GATT secretariat report that the reductions in tariffs be speeded up.

The minister has not given us any comfort in saying that the government would reject any such requests; nor has he done that in relation to the TCF products. In relation to TCF products, it should be noted that we are now the only country with a textile industry of note that has removed all quantitative restraints. We still have some tariffs in place. But when the manufacturing costs in China are one twenty-fifth of the manufacturing costs in Australia, even tariffs of 40, 50 or 60 per cent would be of no consequence.

Returning for a moment to the car industry, I think it is also worth noting that other countries, including some of the ones that have complained about Australian tariff reduction programs in the car industry, have tariffs which are in excess of Australia's current 35 per cent tariff. Korea has 55 per cent on its cars; the Philippines, 50 per cent; Thailand, 121 to 189 per cent, depending on the size of the car; and Malaysia, 140 to 300 per cent. Clearly that is well above the protection for our industries.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

The promise by the Labor Party for it to be rebated was made in the last election. It has taken a very long time indeed for this much to come about. But in the giving of his answer, the minister specifically indicated that densitometry testing would not be available by way of checking and testing without previous diagnosis, or words to that effect.

I want to refer the Senate to an answer that he gave to Senator Patterson in October 1993. The question was in nine parts. The first part was the relevant one asking whether the government's budget commitment to densitometry testing depended on funding from states and territories. He answered no to that. But then he went on and said:

In the 1993-94 Budget, the Government has committed funds to improve access to bone densitometry testing through the provision of a Medicare rebate. As funding arrangements for bone densitometry testing will be provided through the Medicare Benefits Schedule (MBS), cost-sharing arrangements with the States and Territories are not applicable.
In the second part of the answer he went on to say, in part:

Experts, however, agree that bone densitometry is a valuable test in the diagnosis and management of established osteoporosis and other bone density related conditions. It is on this basis that the Government will improve access to bone densitometry testing in Australia.

My question today related to the rebate for those who are affected, or who are liable to be affected, by osteoporosis. It was in regard to the latter part of the answer that the minister prevaricated and indicated that he was still thinking about it, even though he conceded last October that experts agree it is a very valuable test.

PARA.TAB: The point of testing for osteoporosis is to check as early as possible in the life of a person, when she may be heading in the direction of getting osteoporosis, rather than waiting until the disease is onset. Any woman at the stage of menopause should have the bone testing done. She may then be told—as I was—not to come back for five or 10 years. At least that told me something about my condition at that time. It would tell other people as well. It would also indicate at that stage whether a woman was liable to be at risk.

I urge the minister to stick by what he said in October 1993—that the test is valuable. Those who are liable to be affected by it should have the opportunity to have the test done and pay for it and get a rebate. I am not talking about mass screening of the population or anything of that kind. It was indicated in the minister's answer last October that the government was not intending to establish a population based screening program. At least, it should not just stop there. It will be helpful for those who have osteoporosis, or those who have a condition that would indicate to any physician that the person may already have the disease. I welcome that much. I ask the minister not to go so far back on his commitments as to suggest that women who are clearly within the range and age group of those likely to contract the disease cannot go and have this test done and get a rebate for it.

The minister must be aware that the population is rapidly ageing. There are more people over 65 years of age than ever before. There are more people over 80 years of age than ever before. These numbers clearly will grow over the next 30 years. The cost and the suffering of older women in particular, who are in nursing homes with broken bones and problems that occur from osteoporosis which has not been diagnosed properly, are enormous, and steps should be taken to at least minimise it, if not defeat it.

The minister is doing the government and himself no favour by prevaricating on this issue and not taking it seriously. I urge him to do so, and to take the advice which he gave in October—that experts are in agreement that it is a valuable test. I urge the minister to do something by way of prevention and not wait for a cure that is not yet available.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Health (Senator Richardson) to a question without notice asked by Senator Margetts this day, relating to the Australia's high levels of household waste.

SPEECH.PARA: This was not a detailed, technical reply, and therefore it was disappointing, having looked at the text of the prepared answer, that it was kept from the Senate at the time the minister was answering the question, because people would see that it was a detailed attempt to justify the lack of political will and hence of effective action on the very serious environmental and economic problems which are associated with those issues in Australia.

PARA.TAB: The methodology may have had some imperfections, but the fact that Australia is ranked so low must be cause for concern. How can those people doing international studies hope for a detailed or accurate comparative assessment of one nation with another when Australia has failed to provide the information which would have been required to reach such an accurate assessment and detailed comparison?

There need to be fundamental changes in such things as waste disposal and air emissions. At the moment Australia is only tinkering around the edges. I give as an example the lead abatement package which came out and which was based totally on the consumer, basically saying, `Blame the consumer and don't get industry to make any commitment at all to change its act'. Our coal, according to the answer, may be low sulphur, but it is also very low energy. Hence we have to use more of it to obtain the same energy outcome. We do not reduce sulphur dioxide emissions by burning more coal; all we do is considerably increase our greenhouse emissions. How blind can we be? One has to refer only to the decision of the federal government in the One Nation statement to see that it supports the coal-powered power station. The government offered tax rebates to people buying private bonds in a coal-powered power station. What kind of commitment is this?

Mention was made in the answer to Kalgoorlie and Mount Isa. Kalgoorlie has not only one of the worst ambient air qualities in the world but also dreadful ground water levels in terms of pollution and cyanide tailing dams which are leaking in all directions. It seems that the situation in places like Kalgoorlie is out of control. Yet the answer says that the government is taking environmental actions in these places.

It is the role of these departments to protect the health and environment of the people of Australia, yet this federal government seems to think we are doing okay. Who are we kidding? We are certainly not kidding the rest of the world when our international statements about our environmental record clearly move further from reality.

It seems that Australia's environmental standards are not enforceable. For all our policies, we do not have the political will or the understanding yet amongst our major political decision makers to make radical changes. We cannot talk about meeting environmental standards unless we change from being a car dependent to a public transport oriented society and unless we increase funding to the better cities program to allow people effectively and efficiently to use public transport. We have cut the funding for these projects. How can we stand up in international arenas and claim we are the best in the world? Clearly we are not because we do not balance our actions with our statements. The hope that this country has that other countries will want to purchase Australia's environmental technology will go down the drain because those countries will be too busy laughing at us when internationally our record is shown to be so far away from our statements.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to support the broad thrust of what Senator Margetts just put before us, even though my emphasis might be slightly different. Like Senator Margetts, when I saw the lead abatement package that came to our offices last week, and when I saw it again in my intray when I got back to Perth on the weekend, I was struck by the thought, `Here we go again'. The government is bringing out these very glossy, great big packages of documents with hundreds of little giveaways, pamphlets and so forth, basically espousing all the good reasons we should get lead out of fuel, paint and so forth.

PARA.TAB: Perhaps cynically, but I think realistically, I came to the view that again this is the sort of environmental initiative that makes the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Mrs Kelly) feel good when an election comes around, when someone asks a question in here or when she goes out to schools. She can then say, `This is what we are doing about lead. Here is another pile of brochures; here is some more information'. But, in the same sorts of terms as Senator Margetts raised, we have to ask ourselves: what does that really do about making our environment better for all of us and for future generations? The answer is that it will probably do very little.

A similar situation has occurred with the government's policy in relation to reducing the use of energy in Commonwealth buildings. About 18 months ago, the Auditor-General brought down a report which said that the Commonwealth government could save something like $40 million a year if it actually implemented its own policy on energy efficiency. I asked a question on notice about this a few months ago and was greeted by the response that, basically, nothing concrete had happened except that a whole load of audits and so forth were going on. Effectively, in the 18 months since that report came down, the Commonwealth has saved no money in energy efficiency. Of course, if the Commonwealth government is spending $40 million more than it needs to a year in burning up energy, one needs only to think about the amount of greenhouse gas that is going into the environment every day because the Commonwealth government cannot even implement its own policies.

The point I seek to make in support of Senator Margetts is that it is all very well having a bureaucracy in Canberra controlling the environment and having a minister who goes around planting trees and launching pamphlets, but unless we actually encourage industries and communities at the grassroots, local community level and business and industry levels—the government does have a very important role here—through a whole range of incentives and infrastructure to behave in an environmentally friendly way, a government based in Canberra, often thousands of miles away from where the action really takes place, will not be successful in creating a better environment.

So I encourage Senator Margetts in her fundamental beliefs. I think we share them. Senator Margetts may say that we can achieve a better environment by regulating industries; I would say we should do it by encouraging them and by doing it in partnership, as I think Prince Charles said when he was here last week. We may differ on how we achieve it but, until we focus on ensuring that at the local level and at an individual level—and, as Senator Margetts would agree, at a household level, where the latest report shows that Australians are very bad at reducing household waste—we will not achieve the objectives which I am sure all senators and members would share.

When I received that lead abatement package it struck me that here again is just more propaganda, more rubbish, literally—I am sure a lot of senators and members would have stuck it in their bins, anyway. A test of that sort of package that comes around to members and senators is: what will it actually achieve in reducing lead in the environment? The real answer is, as Senator Margetts and I both know, very little.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Hill proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

PARA.TAB: Labor's social justice record—sustained record high unemployment, an ever increasing queue of long term unemployed, an increasing gap between rich and poor and two million Australians living in poverty.

INTERJECT.PARA: I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

PARA.TAB: More than the number of senators required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no more important subject that the Senate could be debating today than the gulf between the rhetoric of this government and its record on the appalling state, principally, of unemployment in this nation. The rhetoric of this government is one of social justice, which it defines as a compassionate, fair and just society. That is what it claims to be delivering.

PARA.TAB: According to ABS figures, the record shows that just under one million Australians are still out of work. The term of the long-term unemployed in this country is ever lengthening. We have a more divided society than we have ever had before, that is, with the rich becoming richer and the poor becoming poorer; a record of increasing family breakdown, no doubt linked to these unacceptable levels of high unemployment; and rising crime rates throughout the country, presumably linked to the same issue.

I put to you, Mr Deputy President, that the gulf between Labor's record and what it claims is enormous. One of the saddest aspects of this is that it was the true believers whom Mr Keating thanked particularly for his election victory, yet it is the true believers—those less well off in this country—who are suffering most under the policies of Mr Keating and his government.

There is no doubt that there is a lot in Australia that is wonderful. There is a lot in Australia that Australians find wonderful, but there is a dark side. It is a dark side that this government wishes to avoid. It is this dark side which has come about through poor policy and poor application of policy, which is the subject of this debate today.

I was particularly drawn to this issue by the release last week of a document, Australia's Welfare 1993: Services and Assistance, by the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare. It is a document full of substance and good statistical information as to the state of Australia's welfare. What comes out of that document is extremely alarming. It tells us that more than two million Australians are living below what is defined as the poverty level, which is an increase of some 14 per cent since the last decade. These figures were taken from the start of the 1990s when this government, first under Mr Hawke and then Mr Keating, was well into its decade of government. The result is a 14 per cent increase in those living in poverty.

Furthermore, the numbers of single parent families—which this government claims to support particularly—have substantially increased within that category. Half of the nation's single parent families are defined by this objective independent study as living in poverty. It is a major indictment of this government. This report does just what I said a moment ago; it demonstrates the widening gap between the rich and the poor in this country during the 1990s.

Some of the incidental social information that it brings to our attention is appalling; for example, the fact that in 1990-91 there were almost 50,000 cases of child abuse and neglect reported and investigated by state authorities, of which some 45 per cent of these were confirmed. More than 13,000 homeless people were housed in supported accommodation services. One in four who rent and one in four people aged under 24 were living below the poverty line. These are objective figures produced by an independent and respected authority that should lead this government to hang its collective head in shame.

All the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Howe) could say was that that information is important and useful for us. He made no acknowledgment that Labor's policies of the last decade have, in fact, contributed to this awful state of affairs. Rather, what Labor is trying to indicate to the Australian people is that, because of the cyclical upturn in the economy, the worst is over and good things lie ahead. For many hundreds of thousands of Australians, that is not good enough. Their future is bleak under Labor.

The background is this appallingly high level of unemployment which simply continues and continues under Labor's policies. If we take the last figures produced by the ABS in January, we see that the number of unemployed persons in this country is 962,000. The unemployment rate is 10.7 per cent. Unemployment has been more than 10 per cent per month in this country every month since April 1991. For 28 months this country has had to endure an unemployment rate in excess of 10 per cent.

Of course, there are particular groups within our community which suffer more proportionately. For non-English speakers, the figure is up around 15 per cent. If we break it down even further into certain ethnic groups, we find that the Lebanese community has 34 per cent unemployment and that Aborigines have a 31 per cent unemployment rate—and will not be helped a bit by the government's Native Title Bill. The young, of course, are suffering proportionately more from these terrible figures of unemployment.

It is not just unemployment. One has to add underemployment to it as well. Again, objective research is telling us—and I refer to that research done by Associate Professor Mark Wooden of Flinders University—that there are at least some 600,000 additional Australians who are underemployed. In other words, the statistics really do not tell the full story, because people who work for an hour are off the ABS unemployment statistics. What it means is that we have some 1.6 to 1.7 million Australians who are either unemployed or underemployed. The government wants to forget these figures. They are inconvenient to the image that it is seeking to portray, but it is an image that is inconsistent with its claim of social justice.

Perhaps the saddest part of all this is the trend in long-term unemployment. The figures indicate that those who, unfortunately, become unemployed stay unemployed for longer, almost to the extent where, statistically, they have become unemployable. Recent ABS figures for New South Wales indicate that those out of work for a year or more represent nearly 43 per cent of the total unemployed—up from 35.5 per cent a year ago. The number who had been unemployed for two years or more jumped by 38 per cent, from 48,800 to 69,000—that is, nearly 70,000 Australians unemployed for more than two years have been trying to get a job.

The worst off are the middle-aged jobless—those over 45 years. The figures indicate that they are unemployed for an average period of nearly 85 weeks, compared with 78 weeks in November 1992. More than 24,000 of them had been out of work for two years or more—nearly double the figure of the year before. And so one could go on. Unfortunately, the figures for young Australians are increasing as well. So we have this sad picture of an enormously high unemployment level remaining, underemployment adding to that and those unemployed now being unemployed for even longer periods and therefore becoming less likely to be able to obtain employment.

What is the social consequence of that? What does it mean to our society? I do not mean just the economic consequences—anyone can see that there must be a severe economic consequence to the nation. But this government fails to take into account the real social consequences. Today we heard Senator Crowley's attitude to families. According to Senator Crowley, basically everything is going okay. It is simply not so. A few days ago, ACOSS issued a report headed, `Down but not out'. That report talks about these figures creating a permanent underclass—an expression which we hoped we would never hear in this country again after the Great Depression of the 1930s. In the great egalitarian paradise of Australia, a permanent underclass is being created.

Another study well worth reading was recently put out by Clemenger's. That study talks about the `lost, dispirited youth' within our community. What did these young people who were surveyed on unemployment have to say? The participants said that youth unemployment is so common that they seemed almost resigned to it. What a sad state of affairs in this nation of opportunity!

The message that I bring in the very short time that is allowed in this debate today is that this situation is not good enough and that this government ought to be facing up to its responsibility rather than trying to avoid it. It is just untrue for Senator Crowley to say that families are not under threat. It was simply not good enough the other day for Mr Willis to say that he cannot improve the unemployment figures, thus indicating that the government has almost given up. Further taxes and a jobs levy to solve the problem, which were set out in a green paper, will not work. Another regional development tax to replace the training guarantee levy, which was put forward in a paper issued by Mr Kelty, is simply not good enough.

There are ways in which this government can respond through sensible and practical policies to deregulate the labour market, to lower taxes, to provide incentive, and to provide greater efficiencies within the waterfront and transport sectors. However, the government is not meeting that responsibility and it is about time it did.

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Small Business and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to indicate very clearly that the government rejects this matter of public importance proposed by Senator Hill on behalf of the opposition.
