—If that's the best you can do with a million unemployed, it's not very good—it's disastrous.

—If the opposition claims that one million unemployed is so disastrous, why has it not been elected to government? The opposition has not been elected because the people do not trust it. Last year they rejected the opposition's policies. Only yesterday on television, the—I suspect temporary—Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) rejected a lot of the policies which the opposition so fulsomely promoted in the 1993 election. But nothing has been put in place of those policies—the opposition has said that it basically agrees with the government on bulk-billing for Medicare, the announced tariff levels and a number of other measures. The opposition did not actually say what it would do that is different.

PARA.TAB: Really, it is the height of political hypocrisy to come into this chamber as an opposition in disarray and say, `This terrible government has created unparalleled poverty', when in the last 10 minutes the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Hill) was not able to put one constructive, alternative policy to reduce the terrible level of unemployment and poverty referred to in the proposal.

I agree that 10 minutes is only a short time but I should have thought that the chamber would have heard one suggestion from the opposition about what to do. All we heard was 10 minutes of vented spleen being directed at the government because of the opposition's frustration at losing the last election. As a result, the opposition does not want to consider where, ideologically, it has gone wrong. The Liberal Party does not want to consider the need to completely restructure itself—it is all the fault of the Australian Labor Party for winning the last election.

The opposition has been pushing the line that we have misled the people, that we were deceitful, that we deceived the people. That is what the opposition said after it lost the elections in 1984, 1987, 1990 and 1993. Having said that, at subsequent elections the Australian people still voted the Labor Party back into office. Obviously, the public has made up its mind, whatever problems we may have as a government in dealing with issues—and we do not deny that there are difficulties all the time in government when dealing with issues. The bottom line is that for over a decade the Australian public has said, `We will stick with the government we know. It is getting on with the job, despite the difficulties. It has a compassionate feeling for dealing with the social and economic problems in this country'.

Before Senator Hill starts carping and criticising us, I emphasise the point that he should get his own house in order. This year is the first time in the history of the non-Labor parties that they have nobody in the Senate with ministerial experience. I have checked the record thoroughly on that and I think I am right. Certainly, since the 1940s and the introduction of proportional representation voting to elect senators, this is the first time the non-Labor parties have nobody with ministerial experience, and I think this is showing in the performance of the opposition in the Senate. Now, of course, the opposition is so factionalised that one has to go back to the 1943 election—

TALK.START.PARA: —When?

—One has to go back to 1943 to find an opposition as badly placed as this present one. In the 1943 election there were many anti-Labor parties: the UAP, the Liberal Democrats, the Liberal Country, the Country National, the Queensland Country, the Country, and One Parliament for Australia. I do not know whether One Parliament for Australia was a spin-off of the UAP but, even if it was not, those other parties indicate the disarray in 1943 for the opposition, which was a terrible time for non-Labor. Sir Robert Menzies quite rightly gets the credit for bringing all of those disparate forces together into the present-day Liberal Party.

—Mr Deputy President, I have never before taken a point of order on relevance during an MPI but this is really appalling. This MPI raises the subjects of one million Australians out of work, the length of time of unemployment continuing to increase, and two million Australians living in poverty. The MPI says that this government, elected by the people, should seriously address these major social issues facing Australia. I know that Senator Schacht is the most junior minister the government has but, so far, he has used half of his speaking time and not even attempted to start to address those issues. All he has wanted to talk about is the Liberal Party since 1943. That is a debate for another day; it is not the debate of today. I ask you, Mr Deputy President, to bring him back to the subject before the chamber.

—I am mentioning that to explain why it is that the opposition leader, in speaking in this debate, could not put one alternative policy. Is it because the Liberal Party is in disarray? I was putting the matter in its historical perspective. I think that is quite relevant in an MPI, when we did not get one positive policy initiative from the opposition on this issue.

—Order! The convention about the response by the government in matters of public importance has been that speakers may range as widely as they wish, however obscure the response might appear to be to the mover of the motion.
—I do want to get on to some of the other issues.
—Ha!

—Senator Hill has been successful with that intervention in taking two minutes off my time. I draw attention to the state of the opposition. On the unemployment issue, we do not try to escape and run away from the fact that there is more than 10 per cent unemployment in Australia and more than 900,000 people are registered unemployed. We have copped that criticism over the last three or four years. We copped it in the election campaign and, despite it, the people re-elected us because they thought we were best able to handle the issue of unemployment in a compassionate way.

PARA.TAB: It is pleasing to note that, even though we get no credit from the opposition. We always get blamed for unemployment going up but get no credit when it is coming down. Over the last three or four months 100,000-plus new jobs have been created in Australia and it is estimated that a further 100,000-plus will be created in the next six months. So we will double the budget estimate on jobs being created in Australia.

We should always recognise that the decline in unemployment will be made more difficult by some of the structural adjustments going on in our economy, as well as by the ever increasing percentage of people seeking employment. Now we have the participation rate running at around 63 per cent of the work force, compared with only 60 per cent in the early 1980s. So benefits are really starting to come through in the Australian economy.

On the general issue of poverty, I draw the Senate's attention to an article that appeared in November last year in the Independent monthly. It was a review of a book called Living Decently, written by Peter Travers and Sue Richardson. They made a real effort in that book to measure poverty and not just make assertions, as so many people do. Concerning the results of the study, the reviewer says that the book states:

SPEECH.PARA: Our study has detected little that would justify the current gloom about inequality, poverty and general misery in Australia that is a favoured theme of editorial writers, welfare lobbies and some academics.
The reviewer goes on to say:
Travers and Richardson, it might be said, have undiscovered the poverty so much talked about since the late 1960s.

PARA.TAB: Inequalities in current incomes are largely offset by assets and leisure. Full incomes in the top quintile (20 per cent) are only 2.6 times those in the bottom quintile. Some of that disparity will be a function of age differences. Men and women do equally well overall.

SPEECH.PARA: He finds it even more remarkable that the book says:
being unemployed or out of the labour force is not significantly associated with lower incomes (in any of its varieties) for either men or women.

I know that remark would receive some criticism. People might not find that easy to believe, but I think this article does draw attention to the fact that poverty is nowhere near as bad as the doomsayers opposite make out.

TALK.START.PARA: —This debate is about the social justice record of the Labor government. The legacy of the government is not just a million unemployed. Although I respect the authors that Senator Schacht has just quoted, I do find it a little amazing to hear people saying that poverty is not too bad in Australia. When one understands and knows the human face of that poverty, one certainly cannot make those kinds of assertions.

PARA.TAB: The legacy of the government is not just about the one million unemployed; it is also about those poor Australians who feel very apprehensive and uncertain about the future—the future for themselves, their children and their grandchildren.

I know the term `social justice' can often be academic and is seen to be concerned about all kinds of lofty concepts such as human rights, freedom and so on; but I want to say that today we are debating a very basic and fundamental aspect of humanity. Social justice is about people being able to get food on the table to feed themselves, their children and their family; and about being able to keep a roof over their heads.

There are large numbers of Australians who find it very difficult to achieve those basic goals. I am sorry to say it, but by any measurement this Labor government has failed the test of really living up to its own rhetoric on social justice. I wonder whether it does have solutions, any more than the opposition does. Our social welfare net seems to be becoming more and more threadbare. Income tax cuts have been given to higher income earners, with the support of the coalition, and yet fuel taxes and other consumption taxes have been raised. These impact on lower income earners because the coalition and the government wanted to pay for the income tax cuts which were given. The tax cuts would have been even more unfair if the Democrats had not been able to achieve an increase in the low income rebate.

The really tragic aspect of this debate is that the Liberal and National parties are criticising the government for increasing poverty when they offer no solutions of their own. Looking for social justice initiatives in Fightback is like looking for a needle in a haystack. In that document there are such ideas as cuts in social security payments, throwing people off unemployment payments, throwing women off sole parent pensions and pushing down wages for those in the lower parts of the socio-economic ladder.

Fightback has now been replaced by a complete policy vacuum. I look to the coalition today to propose solutions, not just criticise the government. A further contribution to unemployment is a rampant and deregulated financial sector, interested in profit—not in jobs. This is symbolised by the total opposition to the notion of having even a tiny proportion of superannuation fund investments directed towards job-generating Australian projects.

It is arguable that there may have been a time when there was a correlation between profits and jobs, but this is no longer the case. The similarity of ideas between the government and the coalition has once again been demonstrated by Dr Hewson's announcement yesterday that the coalition will fall in line with the government's tariff reduction targets. I am sure the 200,000 Australians who have lost their jobs, as a direct result of unilateral tariff reduction policy, will be pleased to note that the coalition presents such a significant alternative. I hope the farmers will be reassured that the National Party is not going to follow that strategy. I give credit to my colleague Senator Boswell; he certainly has fought against that policy on behalf of the sugar growers of Queensland.

Economic ramboism is the prevailing theory of economics whose god is efficiency and whose world-wide legacy is poverty and unemployment. This theory views people as expendable and makes enemies of those who end up on the debit side of its balance sheet. I remind the Senate that we do not represent economic theory in parliament; we represent people.

I would like to suggest some of the measures that the Australian Democrats proposed for improving the situation facing so many Australians. We have pushed for a greater investment in infrastructure and Australian industry; a fairer and more progressive tax system; and maintaining reasonable levels of protection for Australian industries and jobs against unfair overseas competition. We want to improve and strengthen the welfare safety net by reducing harsh waiting periods, assisting farmers, bringing levels of income payments closer to the poverty line and greater, more accurately targeted housing assistance and improving income support for those on low incomes or without jobs.

We will be putting forward these measures. They should be in any budget which is serious about addressing social justice issues. We hope the government will consider them seriously. We will be able to see then how genuine the coalition is when it will vote we hope with us in this chamber on poverty alleviation and social justice measures.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —One could today only feel extremely sorry for the unemployed of this country after the speech from the Minister for Science and Small Business (Senator Schacht) on behalf of the government. He said in part that the unemployed thought the government was best able to do something for them. How disillusioned they must be 12 months after the last election to find how very little has been done and how very dismal the prospects are of those who have been unemployed for a long time.

PARA.TAB: Every now and again there is a piece of news which the government trumpets as being good news—and sometimes it is; we have not denied that. But the overriding thing that has occurred with the government's policy and attitude, at least in the last 12 months, is that this group of people, the long-term unemployed, are being left behind and not cared about. They are condemned to being poor, and that is the subject that we are talking about today. One could hardly believe that it could have happened in this country.

The figure of two million unemployed overlooks the number of those who are underemployed, those who have been discouraged from looking for jobs, those in a household where a wife or a husband has lost a job—and that person is not counted as looking for work and needing work because the other party in fact is employed—and those who are unemployed but are not counted because they have done some work as a volunteer. In fact, the number is large indeed. The government seems to be prepared to go on doing the things it is and it just leaves these people behind. This figure of two million represents 13 per cent of Australian households. There are 794,000 households living in after housing poverty as is set out in the Australia's Welfare 1993 review, which has been referred to. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: In 1990, there were an estimated 794,000 income units living in housing-related poverty, about 13 per cent of all income units.
These are the people we are talking about today. These are the people we believe the government should do something about. The report also states:

The high proportion of one-parent families considered to be in housing need in Australia is alarmingly high. Almost 50 per cent of one-parent families—families overwhelmingly headed by women—were in poverty after paying housing costs in 1990.

These are the people that we want the government to take notice of. There is no doubt that as a consequence of this the number of young people who are homeless has risen enormously. Almost half of those living in poverty are with single parents, as I have mentioned. Twenty five per cent of all young people under 25 years live in poverty.

PARA.TAB: I refer to the report of the National Inquiry into Homeless Children by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, which stated a conservative estimate of 20,000 to 25,000 homeless youth. However, Fopp, in his report of 1989, estimated the number of children and young people who were homeless or at serious risk of becoming homeless at 50,000 to 70,000. These are large numbers of Australians that we are concerned about. Those opposite cannot have forgotten the comment of the previous Prime Minister on 23 June 1987 when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: The greatest resource in Australia is not something that we can grow or dig up from the soil. It is the capacity of its people, our great human resource: and above all, the resource of the future—the children of Australia.
He also said:
So we set ourselves this first goal: by 1990 no Australian child will be living in poverty.
That was not met, as everybody knows, and it has got worse since that time. It is time that the government recognised this fact and was prepared to do something about it.

PARA.TAB: The Hawke and Keating governments ignored the warning of the 1970s commission of inquiry into poverty pointing to unemployment and family break-up as important factors increasing the risk of poverty. Notwithstanding that, they were prepared to bring on to this country the recession we had to have, with the increased levels of unemployment, which we still have; the growing long-term unemployed; and, as a consequence, the increased levels of poverty.

Six hundred and thirty six thousand children are living in single parent families, the majority of which are on supporting parent benefits. Five hundred and forty four thousand children in Australia have neither parent or, in the case of sole parent families, their only parent in employment. There are a lot of children being seriously disadvantaged and the impact of that will live with them for a very long time. Poverty is not just a matter of lack of food and lack of housing, which are the prime matters that people are most concerned about, but it is more than that. It is lack of sufficient resources to participate in the usual activities of the society to which they belong; lack of ability to participate and be an active member of the society; and a feeling of being left out.

I do not think the government has the slightest comprehension of what it really means. It talks about numbers. The minister referred to an increased number of advertisements for jobs. That is one aspect but we are talking about the real people who are living in poverty as a consequence of this. Do not forget that women have borne the brunt of much of the increasing poverty and the social inequality which has risen over the last 10 years.

We are talking about unemployment and poverty; we are not just talking about income. We are talking about the mental and physical health of the people involved, of family stability, of crime rates, of youth homelessness and the capacity of millions of Australians to behave like Australians—to be a part of this society. There is undoubtedly greater sickness amongst the poor. They are being left behind and the government knows this. In 1988 the government was told about this matter by its own economic planning advisory council. It said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . many low income people, especially families with children, have to survive on insufficient nutrition, are unable to heat their homes in winter, are often unable to afford medication, and are denied most forms of recreation . . .

Labor has abandoned these people and does not care about them. They suffer from a loss of self-esteem, a loss of a sense of value and self-worth, a feeling of not being wanted and a loss of dignity. They are becoming the have-nots in our society. EPAC also told the government that if unemployment was 6.5 per cent there would be 800 fewer divorces. Think of the impact of that upon children. Unemployment still remains at over 10 per cent.

PARA.TAB: It is certainly necessary to have mechanisms to support people who fall into this category and are living in the terms and conditions that I have referred to. But it is indeed important to change other things in our society so that changes can take place, so that there will be more wealth and so that those who now cannot participate will be able to do so.

The government could be making genuine industrial relations reforms and work practice reforms. It could be encouraging businesses to invest instead of imposing greater costs on them so that it is impossible for them to survive. It could be making genuine tax reforms. There are a lot of things the government could be doing if it only acknowledged that the long-term unemployed and those living in poverty actually exist. Just because we cannot see them, it does not mean that they are not there.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not surprised by the coalition's contribution to this debate. I am sure that this matter of public importance has been put forward as a distraction from the coalition's current leadership crisis, but I would have thought that it would make some effort to put forward its alternatives. (Quorum formed) The coalition has not only called a quorum, but also, I am afraid, given me the splutters—
—They would make anybody choke and gag at the moment.

—Exactly. We are debating the government's social justice record and I was just saying that I cannot understand why the coalition would come into this place to raise the issue of high levels of unemployment—which, of course, concern all of us—but with not one policy. It is all very well for those opposite to run through a catalogue of our supposed sins, but they are not in a position to put forward one positive policy themselves. Even when Senator Reid made an effort to put forward some suggestions, they were all business related—they were related to the market economy and leave it to the market. I am rather disappointed that Senator Hill brought forward such an important matter of public importance without necessarily putting forward the coalition's strategy.

PARA.TAB: I have no problem defending the government's social justice record. Over nearly 11 years this government has had a very fine record of its recognition of a social wage, Medicare, labour market programs—we have spent $9 billion on labour market programs—income support, rent assistance, public housing, community services, aged care policies, child-care policies, disability services and, of course, infrastructure spending. This government is absolutely committed to the public sector and to ensuring that we provide the social fabric of a society that will support people while they are unemployed. Its report ignores the progress made by the government in housing affordability through reforms to the rent assistance program and fails to critically assess the validity of the Henderson poverty line as a poverty measure. TALK.START.PARA: —I think she would bring the chaos theory to the coalition?

—I think that is most likely. The statistics that our government has in relation to support for families are clearly available. Whichever area of income support measure we choose, we see that over a 10-year period there has been a dramatic increase in the support given to these families. PARA.TAB: If I remember rightly, the jobsearch and newstart allowances were to be cut dramatically in the coalition's proposals prior to the last election. A single young person who is totally independent has had a 50 per cent increase. A single person over 60 has had a 37.5 per cent increase. A couple with one or two children has had a 109.4 per cent increase in rent assistance and a couple with three or more children has had a 138 per cent increase. If we contrast those kinds of statistics with the coalition's record between 1975 and 1983, we find that the coalition's record is one of cutbacks. What was the real change for a sole parent with two children who was renting privately? It was minus three per cent. For a pensioner couple with two children it was minus 2.2 per cent. For jobsearch allowees it was minus 18 per cent. For pension couples it was minus two per cent.

Quite clearly, it is extremely unacceptable for us to imagine that the coalition has put forward a serious debate this afternoon. Those opposite are merely seeking to distract attention from their own woes—the fact that there is such division and they are leaderless and without policy. This government has a very strong record and in the next budget those opposite will see many new ideas brought forward to overcome unemployment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating a very important issue today, namely, the Labor Party's record on social justice. For a party that purports to represent the worker and the underprivileged, it has done a pretty lousy job in this social justice package.
—They have created more of them.

—Yes, this government has created a vast difference between the well-off and the not so well-off. For a party that is supposed to represent egalitarianism by narrowing the gap, it has been an absolute failure. That is not only the feeling of the National and Liberal parties, but also borne out in the recent inaugural report brought down by the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare. It said that two million Australians were living below the poverty line, 937,000 people were officially unemployed, and half the single parents were also living below the poverty line. That is a pretty shocking indictment of the Labor Party. I emphasise that it is not a charge levelled by the coalition but contained in a report of an institution set up by the government.

PARA.TAB: It is the government's responsibility. Labor has been in government for 11 years and cannot blame anyone else. These figures stand as a monument to the government's absolute incompetence on how to manage anything. It has wrecked the small business sector—the provider of most jobs in Australia—and it has wrecked the rural sector. What it has provided for Australian unemployed is mickey mouse jobs and a few throw away things.

A training levy of 1.5 per cent has been inflicted on small business, and additionally there is a superannuation levy of three per cent on small business, which will increase to five per cent, then eventually to nine per cent and then by the year 2000 to 12 per cent. The Treasury warned the government that that levy alone would cost 100,000 jobs. What did the government do? It pushed ahead with it and, of course, it has resulted in an unemployment figure of 11 per cent. That figure has fallen slightly to 10.4 per cent because of a recovery that is in no way due to the Labor Party's policies but more to global recovery.

We have heard from Senator Reynolds and Senator Schacht that the opposition has no policies and that we are not offering any suggestions. Here are a couple of suggestions in the negative that the government should not be doing. The suggestions are that the government should not impose superannuation levies and training levies, then double that with a big king hit and then again put interest rates up to 23 per cent. The government wonders why it gets record unemployment of one million people and discovers, through one of its own department's findings, that two million Australians and half the single parent families are living under the poverty line.

If there is any government that has killed the goose that laid the golden egg, it is this Labor government. Because of the present government's policies of which I have just reminded the Senate—the government's superannuation levy, its training levy, and high interest rates—the results have been that 100,000 15-to-19-year-olds cannot find work; 16,000 people in this age group have been trying to find work for more than two years; and 6,000 people in this age group have been looking for work for over two years. In the 20-to-24-year-old age group, 31,000 people have never worked at all and 8,000 people in that age group have been looking for their first jobs in two years.

In last year's budget the government committed $120 million, on top of the previous year's allocation of $1.2 billion, to create more jobs. We have jobstart, jobtrain, jobskill, jobclubs, skill care and a few other mickey mouse schemes. In other words, we have the most highly trained unemployment sector in the world. These people are getting sick and tired of being trained for jobs that they will never get. When one talks to them many of them say, `I just couldn't possibly go through another jobtraining scheme. All I want is permanent work where I can earn some money and be an asset to my community'.

The government has provided a generation of children who find themselves trapped in the system, without a chance of ever achieving a reasonable position in the community. They are left with temporary housing, caravan parks or are on the street. These are the sorts of things that this new report that was brought down in the last couple of weeks points out. SPEECH.PARA: RESPONSE BY MR T.T. VAJDA
AGREED TO BY MR VAJDA
AND THE COMMITTEE OF PRIVILEGES
PURSUANT TO RESOLUTION 5(7)(B) OF THE SENATE OF 25 FEBRUARY 1988

I was the subject of remarks in the Senate on 20 May 1993 by Senator Short (see pages 941 and 942) which were seriously damaging to me. As the Senator himself acknowledged explicitly (page 942 1st column, 5th paragraph), they were based on a report in the Sydney Morning Herald of 27 March 1993. My letter to the editor of the Sydney Morning Herald the next day denying the allegations was not published.

On 21 June 1993 my legal representatives wrote to Senator Short pointing out in detail the many errors in the Sydney Morning Herald article, and consequently in his remarks to the Senate. Senator Short again spoke on the matter in the Senate on 15 December 1993 (pages 4740 and 4741). There are further errors in what was said on that occasion.

I had nothing to do with the arrest or interrogation of Mrs. Magda Bardy and her then husband in Hungary in 1951. Senator Short's claim that I signed the arrest document of Mrs. Bardy's husband was not correct. The documents which it appears I signed in relation to Mrs Bardy and her husband were final decrees, recording administrative decisions made by the head of the State Defense Authority, and in fact prepared for signature by my then superior, Colonel Juhasz. These documents had nothing to do with arrest or interrogation, but came into existence only after a person had been interrogated, and recorded the decision of the head of the State Defense Authority as to what next was to happen to the person.

Far from being a Stalinist "hard-liner", I was myself arrested and imprisoned in 1953 by the "hard-line" Rakosi regime as part of a "Zionist conspiracy" fabricated by the Hungarian regime following upon the notorious "Jewish doctors' trial" contrived in Moscow by Stalin. I was tortured for five months to confess to being a zionist spy and conspirator. I was sentenced by a closed military court on other trumped up charges, not maltreating prisoners or preparing false statements.

I was sentenced to six years and served nearly four, before being released on 15 October 1956 by the moderate Kadar regime. The Russian army invaded Hungary on 4 November 1956, and far from seeking to associate with the re-instated "hard-liners", I fled Hungary on 24 November 1956.

I came to Australia on a boat with hundreds of other refugees from the Hungarian hard-line regime, and have lived in Australia under my own name, and have chosen to associate closely, both professionally and socially, with the Hungarian community in Australia, a community which of course includes victims of the sort of behaviour of which I am accused by Mrs. Bardy.

I achieved international recognition in dentistry, and have been invited to lecture at universities and international congresses in 19 countries. From 1969 I was many times an invited lecturer at the Scientific Meetings of the Hungarian Dental Association, held at the University of Medical Sciences in Budapest. Since 1969 I have visited Hungary 22 times, including occasions in 1991 and 1992 after the change of government. On all these occasions my lectures have been advertised under my name to all Hungarian dentists.
MR T.T. VAJDA

The speech read as follows—

The training guarantee scheme was established by legislation introduced into the Senate on 18 May 1990, and it came into effect on 1 July 1990. It requires employers to spend a minimum amount on training.

SPEECH.PARA: The scheme was introduced as part of the government's policy over the last several years to develop the appropriate environment in which Australian industry can become more competitive internationally. A fundamental step in this process is the development of a highly skilled work force which can adapt quickly to major changes in the economy. The scheme is an additional mechanism to stimulate industry's commitment to training. As the signs of economic recovery strengthen, we must be prepared for an increase in demand for skilled people. The training guarantee provides an important underpinning to achieve this skilled work force.

PARA.TAB: This bill amends the principal act to give effect to two amendments promised by the government in the election context and also includes other amendments to minimise compliance costs and give greater flexibility to the scheme. In line with election commitments, the bill provides employers with enhanced flexibility to plan training expenditure over a longer period by allowing excess eligible expenditure incurred in one year to be carried forward to the next year. Although this excess expenditure cannot be carried forward indefinitely, it will assist those employers who have a need to train extensively within a short time frame, but whose training needs may not be so great in the following year.

At the same time, and in keeping with the same principle, provision is made for employers who have a training expenditure shortfall in one year to make it up through additional training expenditure in the following year. This avoids hasty and unplanned expenditure simply to meet the minimum training requirement.

The government also committed itself to remove the need for employers to deduct training subsidies provided by government bodies for apprentices and trainees when calculating their net eligible training expenditure. To avoid anomalies, this provision includes any program with training subsidies. As a consequence of this amendment, the minimum allowable apprentice or trainee amount, or `deemed amount' as it is also known, has been doubled to preserve the full incentives effect. It maintains ease of administration for employers who choose to claim the minimum allowable apprentice or trainee amount. Subsequent to the introduction last year of clauses relating to work experience for students and teachers, it became apparent that full-time students 21 years and over were suffering discrimination. The bill removes this anomaly.

The bill widens the range of entities which can group for the purposes of the act thus giving organisations greater flexibility to maximise their training opportunities. It also specifies that businesses must be related at 30 June to form a group for that year and that a business cannot be a member of more than one group in a particular year. In order to avoid complications concerning responsibility for a shortfall or ownership of an excess, businesses which group will not have access to the carry forward provisions.

To rectify confusion about who is able to design and approve an eligible training program, the bill simplifies these requirements. It specifies that the person or persons who design or approve the program must, between them, have a working knowledge of the subject area of the program and the skills necessary to design or conduct the relevant type of training program.

The bill rectifies anomalies about the use of equipment for training by extending the concept of eligible training expenditure. It will now include rental, hire, lease or depreciation expenses on property or equipment for any part of the year during which the employer uses the property or equipment specifically for eligible training programs.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, the bill aligns the training guarantee legislation with a recent amendment to the Australian corporations and securities legislation relating to the appointment of an administrator for liquidation purposes.

PARA.TAB: In summary, this bill encompasses a number of measures to make the legislation more business-friendly, especially for the small business sector. These amendments offer significant benefits to business and their retrospectivity to 1 July 1993 will ensure their immediate use on receiving assent. I present the explanatory memorandum to this bill. I commend the bill to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall make my remarks on the Commonwealth Electoral Amendment Bill 1993 brief. Ostensibly, it is a non-contentious matter. However, I have foreshadowed with the government and other senators the opposition's intention to move at the committee of the whole stage what we think are some fairly non-contentious, minor amendments to tighten up the bill.

PARA.TAB: The purpose of the bill, as set out in the second reading speech and the explanatory memorandum, is to make a technical amendment to the Commonwealth Electoral Act in so far as there is provision in the existing act to appoint state surveyors-general, as they are known in most states, to electoral redistribution committees. This act has to be amended because, in the two fantastic states of Western Australia and Queensland, where as a child I spent almost an equal amount of time—and during most of my childhood they were both run by conservative governments, so it was a very happy childhood—it has been decided to abolish the office of surveyor-general. The act has to be amended to accommodate that change.

As a matter of policy, the government has sought to create a broader definition for the reason, we presume, that every time a state government decides to change the name of the surveyor-general, or the person who undertakes those duties, we will not have to come back to amend the act. The coalition has reached the conclusion that it would be better, in dealing with something as potentially contentious as redistribution committees, for us to ensure that we are a little more specific about the people within state governments who are nominated to serve on redistribution committees.

Because that was the overwhelming view of the coalition parties, we have had some amendments drafted. Those amendments were given to the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator McMullan)—who I understand had them looked at by the Australian Electoral Commission—the Australian Democrats, the Greens and Senator Harradine. Last Thursday the minister's office came back to me with a couple of minor drafting difficulties, which we have addressed. Our initial draft amendments have been altered to take into account the difficulties the government had with the drafting. We hope that the amendments are now in a form that overcomes those problems.

However, I understand that we are probably now dealing with a policy difficulty as opposed to a drafting difficulty—that is, whether it is better for the act to be quite specific about who is appointed to the redistribution committees or whether we leave it in general terms. I can understand the argument that there is merit in having it more general so that we do not have to come back should the South Australian, Tasmanian or some other government decide to change the name of the officer responsible under this act. However, in view of the small amount of legislative time that is required to go through the process we are undertaking today of appointing someone to a body that can become controversial when it comes to redistributions, there is indeed overwhelming merit in actually being more specific. In the amendments which I foreshadow, in the case of Western Australia we have specified the Chief Executive Officer of the Department of Land Administration and in Queensland, the Director-General of Lands.

With those remarks, I seek the support of senators on the cross benches. I understand that the government is not minded to support the amendments. I had brief discussions last Thursday with Senator Lees. Although we have not discussed it since then, I would urge her support. It is not a life and death thing that the opposition will die in a ditch over, but we think it is a sensible way to go. With those remarks, the opposition will be supporting the bill, which we will be seeking to amend.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the Commonwealth Electoral Amendment Bill 1993, I would like to go through the current situation so far as redistribution committees are concerned. Following the announcement of a redistribution, the redistribution committee is appointed. For each state, the members of the committee are the Electoral Commissioner, an officer from the Australian Electoral Office, the surveyor-general and the auditor-general. Today we are talking about only the position of surveyor-general.

PARA.TAB: I take Senator Campbell's point. Indeed, we spent quite a long time in our party room looking very carefully at this legislation to make sure there could not be any blatant political appointments to what is a very important committee. When we get down to reading the precise wording of the legislation it can be seen that it is quite specific. The Australian Democrats do not believe it can be used to put someone who could perhaps best be described as a party hack into what is a very important committee position.

The legislation specifies that the person appointed must have the function of the office, the same as—or substantially the same as—or include the functions that would be performed by a surveyor-general for a state. So whilst acknowledging the concerns that Senator Campbell has, we will not be supporting the amendments, even though it would be a relatively easy process to come back here for South Australia, then Tasmania and then maybe New South Wales.

There is also the possibility that the Queensland or Western Australian governments could change their minds again and redo what is now being done. I think we now have five Liberal governments and one Labor government. I do not know whether any will change, but no doubt over the next few years there will be some changes. They could very well decide again to redefine the position.

The Democrats finally came down on the side of the legislation as it is written rather than asking for further detail and further explanation. Having made those comments, I would just like to say that we have no problems with the rest of the bill. It is quite a small piece of legislation, though quite an important one when it comes to the definition of this particular position.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin Sen N.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the opposition's proposed amendments to the Commonwealth Electoral Amendment Bill and express my grave disappointment that the Australian Democrats do not see the wisdom of what we are proposing. I think I was the first to raise with our shadow minister the problems in this bill. It really proposes that an unidentified state minister can appoint someone he or she thinks holds an office equivalent to that of surveyor-general to the very important body of federal redistribution committee of that state. I think that is an unsatisfactory process, an unsatisfactory wording. It is far too loose. For the purposes of formations of governments federally, the committee is the most important of all bodies. We will persist with our amendment but, as I say, I am disappointed that the Democrats do not see the wisdom of supporting it.

PARA.TAB: I would like to take this opportunity to refer to a few things that are not in this bill. Federal redistributions are one of the most important processes this parliament can discuss. It is an opportunity to put on record some things I think are currently wrong with the redistribution procedures currently in force in the federal sphere. It is true that Australian redistribution processes are, by and large, relatively open and relatively independent, particularly compared with the United States of America, which, as many honourable senators know, has what I regard as an utterly biased and politicised process. The fights over elections to governor are keenly fought because the governor of each state has an enormous influence on the federal boundaries in each state for the House of Representatives. Many honourable senators would have seen the extraordinary electorates that ensue. The United States now has a proposal whereby certain electorates must be majority black, which means that the Unites States has electorates that look like the river Murray and flow in a very thin stream throughout one state in order to gather up enough blacks to form a black electorate. I pray that we never get that sort of nonsense in this country.

Despite the apparent fairness of our system, there are a few anomalies that I wish the government would pay attention to and proceed to do something about. One of the major anomalies is the inconsistency in the use of population between the number of seats per state and enrolment for the actual drawing of boundaries. It is an anomaly that not many people have focused on but one which I think is very significant. Two different sets of numbers are used for the determination of the number of seats and for the drawing of the actual boundaries.

I am pleased to see Senator Foreman in the chamber because this anomaly produces a particularly perverse result in South Australia. The South Australian boundaries were, as most honourable senators know, redistributed in 1991. Because of the population criteria that are used, the number of seats in South Australia was reduced from 13 to 12, giving South Australia two fewer seats than Western Australia—the state most comparable in population. However, if we look at the statistics, we find that Western Australia at that time had only 10,000 more electors but ended up having two more divisions. So we ended up in a situation where Western Australia had only, in effect, 1/8 more of a seat in terms of voters—that is what we are talking about when we talk about seats; we think in terms of voters; that is, one vote one value—but, because of this anomaly, Western Australia ended up with two more divisions, or 160,000 effective equivalent votes, than South Australia. So Western Australia now has 14 votes in the house and we have only 12, despite the fact that both states basically have the equivalent number of voters.

In 1991, the average enrolment in the 12 new South Australian seats was 80,674 but, in the 14 seats that Western Australia had, the average enrolment was only 69,883 because of this perverse situation. Therefore, a vote in Western Australia was worth a heck of a lot more than a vote in South Australia. That is really not one vote one value. It is an anomaly that I think is ridiculous. In my view, if enrolment is going to be the basis for drawing boundaries, the number of seats in a state should be based on enrolments. So we have a situation now where South Australia has by far the highest average enrolment and therefore a vote in South Australia is worth less than in any other state in the country.

South Australia's average enrolment is now 84,097 voters. The next highest is recorded at 78,677—6,000 less. In Western Australia, it is only 74,574—10,000 voters less per seat. Yet, the poor members in the South Australian seats have only the same resources, the same mail allowances and everything else. There are a lot more consequences than simply the worth of the vote. There is also the practical issue of the services provided to members of parliament to service a lot more voters. Of course, Tasmania has only 64,000 voters per seat compared with our 84,000. It really is a very significant issue that I urge the government to pay attention to.
The second issue I would like to raise in relation to redistributions is the requirement that the redistribution committee for each state—which is what we are talking about:

SPEECH.PARA: must, as far as practicable, endeavour to ensure that 3 yrs & 6 mths after the Redistribution, no Division will deviate by over 2 % from the average divisional enrolment at that time.

In other words, it is referring to the two per cent measure at the halfway point between redistributions. I do not know how many honourable senators have actually been involved in the detailed work of trying to draw up boundary submissions to the redistribution committee but it is an extremely difficult job. I, as state director in South Australia, had the task last time of doing it simultaneously with a state redistribution. This particular provision is utterly impractical and unworkable and, in my view, should be deleted from the criteria for drawing boundaries. It makes the task of drawing the boundaries for a state infinitely more difficult. It is ad hoc; it is the tail on the donkey stuff. I am not aware that it exists in any state criteria for drawing boundaries. I think it should go.

PARA.TAB: In South Australia, we currently have the situation where, about a year out from the midpoint, half the seats are well outside the two per cent deviation. The seat of Bonython, where we are about to have a by-election in which the Liberal Party will scare the pants off the Labor Party, is 10 per cent below the projected average enrolment at the midpoint. So in the next 12 months there has to be an eight per cent increase in enrolment in Bonython in order for it to reach this magic two per cent deviation at the midpoint. This is, I would suggest, utterly impossible to achieve. It is certain that several, if not half, of the seats in South Australia will be outside this two per cent deviation by the midpoint, thus establishing that it really is a silly criteria. It makes the process very difficult to achieve and should really be deleted.

The third matter I would like to raise in relation to redistributions is that of political fairness—the political fairness of the boundaries. As the Senate would know, currently there is absolutely no requirement at all that the boundaries be in fact electorally fair. It is only by chance that they might ever be so. The only requirement is that they be roughly equal in size in terms of mandatory requirements. This of course can produce extremely unfair consequences, as my two learned and esteemed colleagues from Western Australia would understand. In fact, in Western Australia in 1990 that unfairness was demonstrated more radically than has previously been the case. In that federal election in that state, Labor got only 47 per cent of the two-party preferred vote but eight of the 14 seats. The Liberal Party, with 53 per cent, got only six of the 14 seats. There has been a no more massive demonstration of unfairness than that, and we are not going to put up with the baloney that comes from the government about targeting and better marginal seat campaigns which it knows to be a nonsense.

Malcolm Mackerras—putting aside whatever people may think of his capacity to predict election results—is probably the best analyst of redistributions and boundaries in this country. In the book The Greening of Australian Politics, he said in relation to the outcome in 1990:
An unbiased person, looking at the maps of eastern and Central Australia—

SPEECH.PARA: for the recent redistribution prior to the 1990 elections—

must say they are very fair. The same cannot be said about Western Australia, the map of whose 14 seats was drawn in 1989 . . . There the maps would seem to have been designed to give the Liberal Party six seats which it would win by large margins . . . while the other eight seats would go to Labor.
He goes on to describe those seats, and then concludes:
So the 1989 redistribution for Western Australia produced a Labor gerrymander.

PARA.TAB: On the point about the supposed `one vote one value' nature of the system, to make electoral enrolments as nearly equal as practicable does not make the system one achieving `one vote one value'. You can still have a gerrymander, as in Western Australia.

Mackerras is an independent analyst of electoral systems and he puts it very well. He has exposed the gerrymander that was produced in Western Australia by the application of these so-called fair criteria. The South Australian parliament, under a Labor government to its great credit, has dealt with this problem of unfairness in the drawing of boundaries and has come up with a remedy for that, which I believe worked exceptionally well in the recent state election. In 1991, under the Labor government—with our support—the Constitution Act of South Australia was amended to provide as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: In making an electoral redistribution the Commission must ensure, as far as practicable, that the electoral redistribution is fair to prospective candidates and groups of candidates so that, if candidates of a particular group attract more than 50 per cent of the popular vote (determined by aggregating votes cast throughout the state and allocating preferences to the necessary extent), they will be elected in sufficient numbers to enable a government to be formed.

There was some controversy about that, but it was a very serious attempt to achieve fairness in the drawing of electoral boundaries—given that in the case of Western Australia federally, and in South Australia in 1989 at a state level, we have seen how unfair boundaries can be.

PARA.TAB: The boundaries were drawn accordingly in South Australia, and in the recent South Australian election the Liberal Party scored 61 per cent of the two party preferred vote. The Labor Party needs a swing of 10.5 per cent to win the next South Australian election. In other words, the boundaries are almost exactly fair because a swing of 10.5 per cent against the Liberal Party, thus reducing it to 50.5 per cent, would give the Labor Party 49.5 per cent and that would be sufficient for Labor to win. There is a slight bias to Labor but, by and large, one would have to say that application of that section of the Act has produced remarkably fair boundaries.

It is my strong view—and I will urge it upon my party—that we should advocate the introduction of an equivalent section into the rules for drawing federal boundaries. It is a very simple thing to do on a state by state basis. The boundaries can be drawn in a way that eliminates a recurrence of the outrageous position that occurred in Western Australia in 1990.
This bill deals simply with the composition of redistribution committees. It is too loose; it needs tightening up. I commend my remarks about the whole process of redistributions to the Senate.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Trade and Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank all honourable senators for their support for the core elements of the bill.
—So you agree with what Senator Minchin had to say?

—If Senator Panizza reads the Hansard he will understand what I said. I thank honourable senators for their support for the core elements of the bill. I would like to mention two things. Firstly, I do not accept the opposition's amendments. I understand the argument that Senator Campbell put. I believe Senator Minchin grossly overstated it. I accept, as Senator Campbell put it, that there is an argument on balance to be weighed between the generic and the specific approaches. It is certainly true that one needs to be scrupulous in examining the legislation which determines the structures for a body with such potential significance as the redistribution committee.

PARA.TAB: I understand the underlying premise, but on balance I think the approach that the government is taking is the preferable one, both in terms of achieving the desired outcome of maintaining the existing structure, and in containing a bit of flexibility to enable the states to go about their administrative reorganisations without impairing our capacity to undertake the redistributions that the act makes necessary. I accept the validity of the point that has been raised. Senator Lees summed it up well. We looked at it on balance, and we came down on the other side. Senator Campbell used the phrase `it is not something you would die in a ditch about'. I share that view, but I come down on the other side in this debate. I understood from her remarks that Senator Lees agrees with me.

I would like to respond very briefly to Senator Minchin's views. Whilst we often disagree about electoral matters, it is a pleasure to hear people in the Senate talking about something that they know something about. The problem—

TALK.START.PARA: —Not many on your side have that problem.
—Oh, Senator Macdonald should not be so tedious. Until he came in this was a decent level of debate.
—Go on!

—Will someone take him out and sober him up, or something. Could I try to take Senator Minchin's argument seriously and lift it above Senator Macdonald's standard? Senator Minchin at least tried to have a decent debate. I have some sympathy with his point about the different ways in which seat distribution takes place but, of course, we are constrained by the constitution. It is not a matter that this bill or the Senate can do anything about, other than by way of initiating a constitutional referendum. That is not something that has a great history of success; nor great history on our part of support from the opposition. I suspect that if we tried, Senator Minchin's colleagues would find a very good argument to oppose it, whatever it might be at the time.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is interesting to note that we have before us the Australian Space Council Bill 1993, a bill of great importance to Australia's space industry, yet the minister in charge of its passage, Senator Schacht, is not in the chamber and has sent in his place a junior minister, Senator Crowley, who I do not think would know one end of a space base from another. However, I am rather pleased that Senator McMullan has left the chamber. He was obviously a little tetchy about things this afternoon. No doubt he has concerns about his part in the Centenary House affair, where the Labor Party has leased office space to the Australian National Audit Office, apparently unbeknownst to it. I imagine that something like that would play on Senator McMullan's mind and make him a little tetchy when he speaks in the chamber.
—And his Canberra-based colleague, Ros Kelly, is under a bit of pressure today.

—That is true. Of course, the whole government is under some pressure, which means it is curtailing ministers' speeches. If we take things like that into account, we should make allowances for the Labor Party and the way its members act in this chamber.

PARA.TAB: The purpose of the Australian Space Council Bill is to establish the Australian Space Council. The council will replace the Australian Space Board and will report to the minister responsible for space activities and policy concerning Australia's role in space. The establishment of the council will cost the government an extra $2.68 million in annual recurrent funding, and will cover administration, salaries and operating expenses.

The bill gives effect to recommendations made in a report into Australia's national space program titled An integrated national space program. The strategy outlined in that report has been generally accepted by the government, and the coalition will not be opposing the bill, which has been based on that report.

The international space industry is primarily concerned with the design, development, manufacture and maintenance of space equipment, together with the provision of ancillary services. There are four main areas of operation: the development and manufacture of satellites for use in areas such as telecommunications, earth observation, and weather forecasting; the manufacture and launch of vehicles to place the satellites in orbit; the construction of ground stations to communicate with the satellites and receive information; and the provision of related services, such as satellite tracking and control services, telecommunications and remote sensing.

Australia's annual space budget is a measly $6 million—tiny by international standards. The big players aside, Sweden spends approximately $122 million and Canada approximately $270 million. A common theme in support of national space programs around the world is that space activity involves a range of leading edge technologies, and that countries involved in these technologies will gain long-term advantages in natural competitiveness.

Space activities have obvious public good and infrastructure aspects—for example, communications, weather and disaster forecasting, and environmental monitoring. A common goal of national space programs is to gain and maintain access to such services in the face of market imperfections in the industry. Space research and development also enables industry to develop in a general sense by enhancing its technical and scientific capability.

Government expenditure to assist industry is only justified from an economic perspective if the private sector fails to generate the patterns of activity which would maximise Australia's overall economic welfare, and if government can improve outcomes in a cost effective way. Government expenditure may also be justified if there is a persuasive case for pursuing non-economic goals—for example, excellence in space science or a contribution to the international community.

In its economic evaluation of the space program, the Bureau of Industry Economics, the BIE, concluded that there were only very limited benefits which Australia might derive from the development of space related industrial capabilities, and that the case for a program must rest primarily on the public good benefits Australia might gain as a user of space technology. That BIE report was not accepted by the expert panel looking into this, nor was it accepted by the government.

As a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure, which inquired into satellite launching in Australia, I was pleased to be involved in the investigation into matters affecting our space industry. It was a matter of concern to me that private development of a space base in north Queensland was not assisted by the state and federal Labor governments to the extent that I and many others felt it should have been. That was a great opportunity for an Australian company to become involved in leading edge technology and the establishment of a major space base in north Queensland, but neither the state nor the federal government pulled their weight when it came to giving that company the encouragement it needed to get the space base operating.

A number of times during the course of the Senate inquiry into that space base, I told the government that it really had to get involved not by giving direct financial assistance, but by meeting environmental and Aboriginal concerns over the project, and identifying someone or some group with whom the couple of companies that were looking at establishing that space base could get in touch to negotiate its siting in North Queensland. Instead of heeding these warnings and taking a can-do approach to ensure that the Cape York space base development became a reality, the Labor government sat on the fence and left the proponents of the base to wade through an incredible amount of red, black and green tape. As a result, it became just too hard and, in the latter half of last year, the proponents of the Cape York space base abandoned Cape York as a site for their base and chose a site in New Guinea. Because of Labor's political meanderings, hundreds of millions of dollars per year and thousands of jobs which should have gone to North Queensland will now go to Papua New Guinea.

At the time of the Senate inquiry, the National Institute of Economic and Industry Research estimated that a space base on Cape York could have added, in 1988 dollars, about $430 million per annum to Australia's GDP; reduced the current account deficit, again in 1988 dollars, by $184 million—about the extent of our present current account deficit; and created 4 1/2 thousand jobs in high technology industries in Australia. Those sorts of benefits would have been available for Australian industry had the government taken a more proactive approach to that particular proposal. Australia does not deserve to miss out on the vast economic and scientific benefits which would come from a space base such as that proposed for Cape York.

With respect to the bill, the government has taken on board the important outcome of the Senate committee's inquiry into satellite launching in Australia. The committee's report recommended that the government give high priority to investigating the need to establish a space policy council and to providing a strategic and operational oversight of a coordinated national space policy and program, and concluded that a council should provide a more effective means of consultation within the space community and a more efficient application and management of existing space related funding. Notably, the committee's report suggested that, if a council is established, its charter must indicate a clear and positive direction for Australian industry, research institutes and other relevant groups.

The bill provides that the council will prepare a rolling five-year strategic plan that includes objectives, strategies, costs and benefits of the integrated national space program. I hope that this plan ensures direction and due recognition and assistance to leading Australian space developments. In this regard, I particularly mention the world leading Scramjet project being researched and developed by Professor Stalker and his team at the University of Queensland—a very important project which will have major ramifications for Australia. I certainly hope that the new Australian Space Council can play its part in encouraging and bringing that very fine project to fruition.

At the time of the last election the coalition policy on this matter was to pass the resources of and responsibilities for the national space program—which includes the space office and the national space council—to the CSIRO's Office of Space Science and Applications. This was to have been overseen by an active space council as currently constituted. Since the last election, there have been changes to the management and structure of COSSA and the management and nature of the space office. As a result, existing coalition policy has been suspended for the time being. The most appropriate policy position for us would now be to look at the operations of the space council and the space program when we return to government. Until that time, we certainly hope that the current proposal results in a positive move towards promoting a national science policy and program. On that basis, the coalition will not oppose the bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —As already pointed out by the minister in his second reading speech and by Senator Ian Macdonald, the Australian Space Council Bill is a machinery bill which gives effect to various historical events. The government created a space board and now this bill seeks to replace that with the Australian Space Council. This was anticipated in the Madigan report of 1985, after which the Australian Space Board was formed; it was also a result of an investigation by an expert panel in 1991-92, which recommended an integrated national space program in a report tabled by the former industry minister, Senator Button. The government's response to that was to accept one of those recommendations, which is to change the organisational arrangements and to create the Australian Space Council, with which the Australian Democrats entirely agree.

PARA.TAB: As Senator Macdonald pointed out, the bill also provides for a wide range of representation from industry and research bodies on this council to fulfil the varied requirements of government, industry and research into space and the different interests of the Commonwealth and the states. It was also pointed out by Senator Ian Macdonald that at the moment the council's program is only a small $6 million a year, but that also included in the funding is the $15 million from NASA for the deep space Tidbinbilla complex which carries out some very important research.

I wish to pick up a couple of other points which were also touched on by Senator Macdonald. Looking at the proposals which have been around for some years for a space base at Cape York, one finds that changing technology has probably superseded that base. The reason for going as close as possible to the equator is to pick up the spin of the earth so that less energy is required to launch heavy vehicles into space. When the Democrats looked at this during the number of years that it was a current proposal, we worried a great deal about its economics and thought, on all our calculations, that that base would have to accept military launches to make it economic. It was a heavy vehicle launching facility, expensive and, contrary to what Senator Macdonald said, the economics looked rather dubious. In the light of that, the considerations of Aboriginal interests and the environment loomed very large indeed.

I would, however, agree with Senator Macdonald on Professor Stalker's Scramjet proposal. This is an exciting development which would allow the launching of very light satellites, light vehicles, from virtually anywhere with very little ground backup and support. So the costs of such launches would be low and would not necessarily have to be done from near equatorial launching stations. For instance, Woomera would be a perfectly suitable place for these launches because, unlike the heavy vehicles launched more directly into space, the Scramjet requires a low trajectory through the earth's atmosphere to attain the escape velocity. I agree with Senator Macdonald's call for more support for Professor Stalker and his Scramjet developments.

This is a uniquely and totally Australian development. The heavy vehicles which would have been launched from a station on Cape York would have involved a great deal of overseas technology. I certainly believe that we should be supporting Australian developed technology and seeing that it could be used here. That would give us—if the Senate will forgive the pun—a launch pad from which we could go into overseas markets with Australian technology rather than importing technology from overseas. So we will be supporting this legislation. We think it is desirable for Australia to push ahead with its own technology in space which, as far as I am aware, particularly involves Professor Stalker's work in the engineering faculty of the University of Queensland.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank both speakers for their support of the Australian Space Council Bill. I will not comment on Senator Ian Macdonald's ungracious remarks at the start of his speech. He soon warmed to the subject. I do not know why I have the short straw of having to listen to him on two successive bills, but I guess I am just lucky.

PARA.TAB: I note Senator Macdonald's and Senator Coulter's remarks on the Scramjet. If I am right I have seen its prototype of it at the North Queensland Shipyards. It is quite exciting, certainly for the next generation of politicians who will be able to get to London in an hour for a CPA conference. It will be of enormous benefit in the future.

Senator Macdonald mentioned that the Liberal Party had a policy—which it has now suspended—on this at the last election. That is true to form. I was most surprised and delighted to hear him say that he had an open mind on this subject. I think that development should be at least marked and noted for the record. I congratulate Senator Macdonald on having an open mind.

Senator Coulter also supported the proposal. I think Senator Coulter at one stage described himself as the James T. Kirk of the Australian Democrats. I will not make any remarks on the next generation of that. This will not be an easy area to break into; I do not think anyone has any illusions about that. Senator Coulter remarked on the potential use of Woomera into the future. Certainly that has been looked at on several occasions. I hope it is looked at again, for I do not think the Nurrungar base will be there forever. I doubt it will be there at the end of this century. Therefore, developing alternative uses for what are quite good facilities at Woomera, be they of this nature or other scientific natures, I think will be of great benefit in future. So, very peripherally, as Minister for Defence, and having an interest in Woomera and the current purposes that basically exist, I would be delighted to see alternative uses so that the township remains viable and can continue in the future. I thank honourable senators for their support of the bill.
