DEBATE.TITLE: WET TROPICS OF QUEENSLAND WORLD HERITAGE AREA CONSERVATION BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 16 December 1993, on motion by Senator Sherry:
That this bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Wet Tropics of Queensland World Heritage Area Conservation Bill provides for the Commonwealth to assist the Queensland government in the management of the wet tropics world heritage area of Queensland.

PARA.TAB: In 1990, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the Premier of Queensland formed an agreement named the wet tropics management scheme, relating to the management of the wet tropics area. This agreement allowed for the creation of the Wet Tropics Management Authority, a wet tropics management agency, which has since been merged with the Wet Tropics Management Authority, a community consultative committee and a scientific advisory committee.

The majority of the terms of this agreement were enforced by the Wet Tropics World Heritage Protection and Management Act which was passed through the Queensland parliament in 1993. As Queensland legislation cannot bind the Commonwealth, the Commonwealth needs to implement complementary legislation in the terms of this agreement to allow the agreement to work to its full extent.

Although the Commonwealth legislation is intended to cover a range of matters, including the Ministerial Council, the two committees and funding, it was decided that, as most of these matters were covered clearly by the management scheme, the Commonwealth legislation would be kept brief.

The Commonwealth bill covers three matters. Firstly, it enables the Commonwealth minister to nominate two members to the six-member board of directors of the Wet Tropics Management Authority; secondly, it enables the Commonwealth minister to make available to the Wet Tropics Management Authority Australian public service staff; and, thirdly, it provides for an annual report of the authority to be tabled in the Commonwealth parliament.

The wet tropics of Queensland world heritage area covers some 900,000 hectares of rainforest between Townsville and Cooktown along the North Queensland coast. The wet tropics rainforests were world heritage listed in December 1990. No-one in north Queensland has ever questioned the need to protect the wet tropics rainforest. However, there was controversy originally about the manner in which the Labor governments, both state and federal, approached the listing. Honourable senators may recall that in those days there was a very great concern about use of foreign affairs powers to enforce the world heritage listing, contrary to the wishes of the Queensland government of the day.

There was also a very great concern about the drawing of the boundaries of the wet tropics rainforest. As I have said many a time, no-one really objected to the listing, but there was a lot of concern about the boundaries and how, through the actions of the government, many livelihoods, small businesses and the town of Ravenshoe were almost completely crucified. Even today, the effects of those listings on business people and workers in Ravenshoe can be felt. In fact, Ravenshoe at the moment has one of the greatest social security problems per capita of any place in Australia. That is principally a result of the work that was taken away.

Then there was the sum of $8 million of Commonwealth funds, taxpayers' money, which through mismanagement of this government just disappeared. In spite of many attempts to explain that over the years, nothing eventuated except to show that this government was not capable of managing even that relatively small amount of money. I understand that there are proceedings in the courts at the present time, and we await the outcome. Since that time things have settled down a bit. Any controversy now with the wet tropics centres on the way the listing has been made by the Wet Tropics Management Authority.

There is a general feeling in the community in North Queensland that the Wet Tropics Management Authority is doing as good a job as it can, as part of an archaic bureaucratic environmental management system which has not kept pace with the environmental progress in the region. This comes as no surprise, as the Wet Tropics Management Authority is essentially embedded in the Queensland government's Department of Environment and Heritage. The board of directors answers to the ministerial council comprising two state ministers, Mrs Molly Robson, the Environment Minister, and Mr Ed Casey, the Primary Industries Minister in charge of forests, and two Commonwealth ministers, Mrs Kelly from the environment portfolio and Mr Michael Lee from tourism.

If I am permitted, I might say—and I hope no-one will think this is sexist; it is just the way it happens—that it is somewhat fortunate that Mr Casey and Mr Lee are able to be involved in that council in order to keep Mrs Robson and Mrs Kelly from some of their more outrageous proposals in relation to the environment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh!

—It is important to consider some of the more extreme environmental pressures on both the state and federal governments. Senator Reynolds will be well aware of this, coming from the Labor Party in North Queensland where there is an unholy row about environmental matters—one of which is the Tully Millstream. A lot of the Labor people in North Queensland believe that it is essential for jobs and secure power but there is another element of the Labor Party, captives of the radical Greenies, who will not let it happen. So there is an enormous problem in the Labor Party in North Queensland. Senator Reynolds will probably tell us about that later. It is good that Mr Casey, the state minister for primary industries, and Mr Lee are to keep a balance on that ministerial council to make sure that tourism and forestry aspects are properly brought to the fore in the discussions on the wet tropics management.

PARA.TAB: One of the concerns in the local community is that the Wet Tropics Management Authority is seen by some as unnecessary because it overlaps the role of the National Parks and Wildlife Service. This is true for about 30 per cent of the world heritage rainforests, which are in national parks and controlled by the Queensland Department of Environment and Heritage, whilst more than 40 per cent of the world heritage area is in the state forest area and is controlled by the Queensland Department of Primary Industries. It is obvious that there must be some overlapping in the roles performed by each of these controlling bodies.

The roles of the organisations are essentially different in that national parks and the state forest office take care of the more day to day practical management tasks while the Wet Tropics Management Authority takes a planning and overseeing role.

Another concern in the community is that the authority spends a tremendous amount of taxpayers' money and at times there is little to show for it. For the three years the authority has been in operation up until November 1993, the Commonwealth government will have provided it, under the guidelines of the management scheme, with $10 million for capital works.

The Commonwealth is also obligated to provide the authority with annual recurrent funding which is matched by the Queensland government. Since its establishment, the authority has received approximately $4 million per annum from the Commonwealth government. This $4 million has been matched by the Queensland government, which has provided $2.5 million per annum from treasury funds and $1.5 million in in-kind funding. This funding actually bypasses the Wet Tropics Management Authority and is spent by the Queensland Department of Environment and Heritage.

I have some concern, of course, with any funding arrangements in which Mrs Kelly is involved, because we know what happens when Mrs Kelly gets involved in funding arrangements. She will not have any trouble here because she is only interested in marginal seats. Regrettably, for the present at least, the wet tropics are in two, possibly three, marginal seats: Leichhardt and Herbert and, to the rear and to the western section, a bit in Kennedy. Mrs Kelly will find it very easy to spend the money there without being accused because I do not suppose she can spend it anywhere else.

I can remember only a few months ago when Mrs Kelly promised to match the Queensland government funding for the buyback of the Starcke property from the developer. Senator Reynolds will remember this instance well because Mrs Kelly promised to provide matching funding. So the Queensland government went ahead believing that the Commonwealth would provide dollar for dollar, which is matching funding. Then it turned out that Mrs Kelly was not quite so concerned. She said, `I am not making that commitment. What I actually meant by matching funding is joint funding.' What joint funding means is actually `some kind of negotiation and consultation'. So there was Mrs Kelly again making a commitment to the Queensland government for matching funding and then trying to interpret the words `matching funding', which are pretty clear to most of us to mean joint funding, but which actually means some kind of negotiation. It is no wonder that Mrs Kelly has again shown her incompetence with the sports rorts affair as she did at the time of the commitment to contribute to the Queensland government in the buyback of the Starcke property.

By November 1994, the authority will have received a total of $29.5 million in direct funding since its establishment. When we are in government, Mrs Gallus, the coalition's shadow minister for the environment, will closely scrutinise this expenditure to ensure that we are getting value for money. We will be supporting the type of work being done and Mrs Gallus will no doubt be looking at improving the service. But we will always be open to suggestions on how the service can be more efficiently delivered.

The authority's expenditure is separated into four different categories: heritage conservation, management planning, community relations and corporate support. The authority's expenditure for the three years that it has been in operation is as follows. For community relations, which deals with such activities as community education, community research, planning, Aboriginal issues and infrastructure maintenance, $7.34 million was spent. For heritage conservation, which involves activities such as fire management, ferals and weeds, endangered species and cultural and heritage issues, only $5.49 million has been spent. For corporate support, which involves administration and wages, $5.36 million has been spent. For management planning, which involves such things as strategic plans for the Daintree, visitor monitoring and landscape architecture, $1.57 million has been spent.

The authority's large total expenditure on community relations is of concern in that a proportion of these relations involves self-promotion. It is of interest that the authority has only recently begun spending more money on heritage conservation than it has on community relations.Some groups in the community feel that the authority should spend more time in its job as a strategic planner and manager rather than in self-promotion and lobbying.

On a recent visit to the Wet Tropics Management Authority, where I was warmly and kindly met by the director—and I thank him for his courtesy—I was rather nonplussed to be told by him with some pride that the authority had just conducted a poll and it found out that its public acceptance had increased remarkably over the last few years. I could have told it that. Since the early days of world heritage and since it has been out of the news, it is obvious that most people have forgotten the angst that they felt towards that whole system, which should, of course, have been directed to the government, not to the authority. That has dissipated and people now see the authority as generally doing a pretty good job.

I was surprised that this poll involved a very substantial sum of money—the director did tell me the amount, which I have not retained—and I wondered whether perhaps that amount of taxpayers' money would not have been better spent on something that protected the environment rather than carrying out a self-promotional exercise by indicating and polling to see how popular the authority was in the north Queensland community.

The Wet Tropics Management Authority's budget for 1993-94 allocated $5.7 million to community relations; $6 million to heritage conservation; $2 million to corporate services; and $1.3 million to management planning. The total expenditure is $15.1 million, which includes $7.5 million in new funding from the Commonwealth government, of which $4 million will be recurrent funding and $3.5 million as a proportion of a $10 million capital works funding for the year.

It is interesting to note that this figure of $7.5 million in Commonwealth funding—the minister might clarify this for me—which is shown in the budget statements of the Wet Tropics Management Authority is quite different from the figure given in the program estimates by the department of environment of $8.5 million. I do not have the page number but the estimates documents that we were given clearly show that the Commonwealth contribution is $8.5 million and yet the Wet Tropics Management Authority shows in its budget that it is getting only $7.5 million from the Commonwealth for the same period.

There is a million dollars missing somewhere. I am always suspicious, as I say, with Mrs Kelly and money and with what happened at Ravenshoe with the $8 million. Perhaps the minister might be able to elucidate for me on the difference between the two figures showing $8.5 million going out of the Commonwealth coffers and yet only $7.5 million coming into the Wet Tropics Management Authority. There may be a simple explanation. If that is the case, no doubt the minister will clarify that.

One other major concern that I would like to mention in the time available to me is the concern in North Queensland that there are far too many different organisations, rules and regulations and separate approvals involved in setting up and running an operation or developing in North Queensland's environmentally sensitive areas. An operator may have to pass through world heritage land under the Wet Tropics Management Authority, national parks land under the Department of Environment and Heritage, state forest land under the DPI, shire land under one, two or perhaps even three or four councils, and endless other regulations involving crown land and crown leasehold. On top of this, there is now the uncertain effect of the Mabo legislation on operators wanting to do things in these areas.

For each of these different types of land an operator has to get different types of approvals and abide by different rules and regulations. One operator that I spoke to in the area told me that he had to get more than 50 different permits and approvals to put into operation one single tourist activity. Many of those different approvals were contradictory. One department would say that he had to do this and another department would say that that was prohibited. It is easy to imagine the confusion which is created and the resources which are wasted with such a system.

The system is so inefficient that preventing and delaying reputable tour operations actually encourages environmental degradation. A tourist unable to secure a seat on a tour to the Daintree because the tour has not been able to get new approvals as a result of all this red tape can actually hire a four-wheel drive vehicle and go belting around the rainforest destroying everything in sight. Yet if the person were part of an organised activity, that would not be possible. The individual in the four-wheel drive will cause the sort of damage to the rainforest that we do not want to see and, unfortunately, that problem is increasing. One of the ways to overcome it is to allow more responsible operators greater access to those areas. It is time that people realised that tourism operators in North Queensland are experts in environmental preservation and are leaders in ecotourism. They have a real interest in preserving and maintaining the environment because they rely upon it for their income.

The wet tropics authority is caught up in the current system in that many of its regulations differ from those of other authorities. One particular case comes to mind where an operator wanted a boardwalk extended at Oliver Creek in the Daintree. The wet tropics authority okayed the extension but then the operator went to national parks for approval and it refused it.

One approach to solving such problems may be to make further investigations into a multitenure arrangement or a one-stop shop so that operators have to secure only one approval from one authority which controls all environmental activities in the one region. The disarray in the system stems directly from the fact that, in my view in my submission, the governments, both state and federal, are completely out of touch with real environmental issues in North Queensland. They have no idea of the potential for ecotourism and the development of the Far North and have lost the ability to legislate effectively in the area.

It is in this respect that I urge the board of directors of the Wet Tropics Management Authority to be stronger in its recommendations to the ministerial council. I further urge consultations between the Wet Tropics Management Authority and its board of directors, the ministerial council and tourist operators. Only by getting together more closely with the people directly involved can we get the sort of legislation that supports tourism, supports a multimillion dollar industry in Australia and yet, at the same time, protects the wet tropics areas and the environment in North Queensland generally. I certainly urge the ministers on the consultative committee, particularly Mr Lee and Mr Casey, to be more pro-active in their role in getting some commonsense resolution to the impediment placed upon the sensible expansion of ecotourism in the wet tropics areas.

As I indicated earlier, the coalition will not be opposing the bill. However, we will continue to closely monitor the government's approach to the world heritage area and to the authority which manages it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to hear that the coalition will not be opposing the Wet Tropics of Queensland World Heritage Area Conservation Bill. Certainly anyone who remembers the history of the listing of the wet tropics for world heritage, the extremism of that debate and the way in which it was politicised to polarise the community will take issue with some of the comments of Senator Ian Macdonald, although I concede that the important thing is that we have cross-party support on this legislation.

PARA.TAB: I would like to take this opportunity to congratulate the Wet Tropics Management Authority for the work that it has been doing. Certainly the Wet Tropics Management Authority started out its life in a difficult climate because the listing of the wet tropics was regarded as controversial and it polarised the community.

While Senator Ian Macdonald questions the sampling of public opinion, I think it is very enlightening to find that, five years after that great debate about the listing of the wet tropics, there is an 80 per cent approval rating for the fifth birthday of the wet tropics. I think it demonstrates the very fine work of the management authority and, indeed, the very fine work of ministers responsible for the management authority, both of whom, I am pleased to say, are women, and exceedingly competent women.

I have to take issue with Senator Ian Macdonald that, while Mr Casey and the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Mr Lee) bring skills to their role on the ministerial council, I certainly do not agree with his derogatory comments about the two women ministers as needing this balance. We have four competent ministers on the ministerial council. They each bring a variety of skills to what is a very important task.

Coming back to the Wet Tropics Management Authority itself, I must say that a great deal has been achieved in the last two years. I would like to run through some of the key achievements of the management authority. They are as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: The release of the Authority's first strategic planning document in 1992 as the forerunner of the draft Wet Tropics Plan due for release early in 1994;
Detailed planning under way for two hot spots—the Daintree/Cape Tribulation area and the Wangetti coast between Cairns and Mossman;
The recent enactment of Queensland legislation to protect the World Heritage Area;
More than $7 million spent on infrastructure projects since 1990-91;
Ground breaking discussions with Aboriginal communities to increase their involvement in the management of their traditional lands;
Liaison with the tourism industry to define its role in presenting the World Heritage Area and to outline the benefits flowing to the community from the World Heritage Area.

I would like to talk a little about the survey which identified this 80 per cent approval rating for the wet tropics because it is significant and it is important to ensure that it is on the public record. The Wet Tropics Update lists the highlights as follows:
Regional support up from 73% to 80%, with the incidence of strong support up from 51% to 59%.
Capital city support relatively steady, up 2% to 72%.
Awareness of the Wet Tropics World Heritage Area up from 31% to 43% in the cities, and from 71% to 87% regionally.
57% of north Queenslanders say the World Heritage Area is having a positive effect on local communities, only 16% perceive a negative effect.

That is perhaps the most revealing statistic of all. Fifty-seven per cent of North Queenslanders say it has a positive effect and only 16 per cent perceive that it will have a negative effect. There has been, the update states:

Significant increases in satisfaction with information provided and progress in decision-making. Tourism and environmental protection seen as the major benefits. Generally support and other indicators are highest in Cairns and Townsville, and lower on the Tablelands and communities south of Cairns.

In recalling the issues of ensuring that the wet tropics would be listed, I well remember the doubts that many people had. Therefore, I am particularly interested to see that the benefits are now perceived as by far outweighing the disadvantages. These are the benefits in order of rating by this survey:
Tourist industry/bringing in tourists
Environmental protection . . .
Preserving something unique/not much left in the world. Beautiful area. . .
Rainforest protection
Ensuring retained for future generations
Stopping development. . .
Preserving a complete ecosystem
Trees provide oxygen/help atmosphere
Wildlife/rare species protected
Enable people to see the area/public access/ recreation
Stopping logging/deforestation
International standing/world recognition . . .
These by far outweigh the disadvantages. The update lists them as follows:
Loss of jobs. . .
Stops logging/timber industry
Influx of foreign tourists/too many visitors
Restrictions on farmers . . .
Restriction of public access
Loss of local control . . .
Land will degenerate . . .

In speaking to this bill, I believe there are a number of issues that we need to consider. There are two proposals for development in the wet tropics area. One has received a great deal of publicity in the past, and I believe will receive more publicity in the future if we cannot work our way through and find a more satisfactory outcome.

PARA.TAB: Senator Macdonald mentioned the Tully Millstream hydro-electric scheme. On a number of occasions this has been raised as being essential to development of the north. Quite clearly, without going into great detail, the scheme is unnecessary and would be an environmental disaster. No-one could take seriously our commitment to the wet tropics if that scheme were to go ahead. Some of the problems identified with this scheme are that the QEC demand projections, on which the scheme is based, are unreliable and do not take into account COAG greenhouse targets adopted in 1992. The impact on the catchment of the Tully and Herbert rivers are severe, and the impact on the wet tropics area would also be severe.

A new project that has been proposed is the skyrail project. Again, there are a number of objections to the skyrail project as currently proposed. While I do not claim to be an expert on the proposal—and I want to have a much closer look at it—I would point out that there are a number of issues about it that concern me.

I am particularly concerned about the commercial exploitation in a world heritage area. I would far prefer to see the Kuranda railway maintained and upgraded than to rely on the private sector to exploit an area. Perhaps I could be convinced otherwise, but at the moment I am not convinced about the skyrail project as proposed. Certainly the organisation PAKS, People Against Kuranda Skyrail, is mobilising its forces to identify some of the problems that presently exist with the skyrail project as proposed.

One of the major things that would concern me is that it would detract from the Barron Falls vista and take passengers away from the Kuranda train, thus denying people an existing and acceptable rainforest experience. This would result in further financial losses and eventual train line closure, thereby cutting off the goods train link to the tablelands. I worry when governments back off and the private sector comes forward. The wet tropics is unique. It should be possible to maintain that Kuranda service, which is so popular. If there is some doubt about that by providing this alternative initially, what about the long-term effect? It is also claimed that the skyrail project threatens to obstruct the Black Mountain wildlife corridor at its narrowest point, which is a connecting link between the Tully and Daintree rainforest regions.

Another issue of major concern is that the Djabugay people, indigenous to the area, do not want the skyrail. They have not been consulted and are most unhappy about the proposal, as presently claimed, going ahead. I emphasise that final approval into the present proposal has not been given. Perhaps there is a way of negotiating through some of these totally unacceptable features.

The other issue that has been raised is safety. Would the skyrail be completely safe? In the event of a breakdown, would rescue methods be adequate? I do not know the answers to these questions. It is claimed that these are some of the issues that have not yet been fully explored. I believe that when we have an area that Australia is caring for—not just on behalf of North Queenslanders and indeed of all Australians but because we are the custodians of a world heritage area—then any tourist proposal such as skyrail has to be very thoroughly analysed. We have to look not just at what the proposal would be in 1995-96, but also at what it would mean in the future. I am pleased to support the legislation, but I hope there will be greater scope for debate about some of these very sensitive proposals.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am a little surprised to hear the concluding remarks of Senator Reynolds, particularly in view of the fact that the federal Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Mrs Kelly) has been asked for an environmental impact statement on the skyrail proposal and has refused to call for one. I also point out that the Queensland minister, whom Senator Reynolds praised as being a fellow female, has also not come up with an EIS on this. I would have thought that the way to properly investigate these things is through the established channels of environmental assessment and proper public display of those assessments. I would very much like to support Senator Reynolds in pressing for Mrs Kelly to call for an EIS on that proposal.

PARA.TAB: The Australian Democrats welcome the debate on the Wet Tropics of Queensland World Heritage Area Conservation Bill 1993. The environmental values of this magnificent area are beyond doubt. I stress that even Senator Ian Macdonald, at long last, is praising the values of this area. As David Attenborough said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Queensland rainforest is one of the most breathtakingly wild areas in the world; unbelievably beautiful, unbelievably interesting. There are birds, mammals, and plants there that are unique. Beyond any dispute, it is a treasure.

PARA.TAB: The wet tropics of Queensland span an area from Townsville to Cooktown. They encompass an amazing array of forest types, from mangroves, paperbarks, to tall open forests and tall medium and low woodlands. They also contain an amazing diversity of species. Although the wet tropical forests cover only 0.1 per cent of the Australian continent—and I stress this figure because very often the pro-development exploiters in our midst will say, `This activity will only damage 0.1 per cent or smaller areas'—they contain 25 per cent of all plant genera in Australia. Approximately 62 per cent of butterfly, 60 per cent of bat species, 30 per cent of marsupial species, 23 per cent of reptile species, 18 per cent of bird species, and 92 per cent of known fern genera are found in that area. Species totally unknown to non-Aboriginal Australians continue to be found almost on a month by month basis. The area also contains over 400 species of rare, threatened and endangered plant and animal species. It is, therefore, vitally important that this area not only be protected as a World Heritage area, but also be properly managed.

The wet tropics are an outstanding example of a major stage in the Earth's history, having survived through millions of years in a moist environment similar to that of Gondwanaland. Only in the rainforests of north Australia, and possibly in New Caledonia, have these conditions been continually maintained since Gondwanaland. The wet tropics now contain the highest concentration of families of ancient flowering plants in the world. It is a magnificent laboratory for those who want to research the evolution of flowering plants throughout the whole of geological history.

Knowing all this, it is staggering to realise that in the 200-odd years since Europeans occupied Australia, three-quarters of the rainforests have been cleared. It is astonishing to look back from our perspective in history at the extent of destruction which occurred until only a few years ago. The protection of the remaining rainforest was, without doubt, one of the highlights of the small assortment of federal government conservation initiatives during the 1980s.

The path to its conservation was not an easy one. A rescue the rainforest campaign was launched by the Australian Conservation Foundation in 1982. In 1983, campaigners targeted the construction of the road through the Daintree from Cape Tribulation to Bloomfield, a road which was nothing short of environmental vandalism. It is interesting to look at the way in which the membership of the Mulgrave Shire and the direction taken by that shire have substantially changed in recent years. In 1984 the rainforest campaign highlighted the logging at Downey Creek, an area of immense beauty. In 1986, conservation groups came together and called for the whole wet tropics area to be protected. During the entire campaign the then National Party government gave full support to the destruction of the forests.

TALK.START.PARA: —We were for the workers.

—On 5 June 1987, World Environment Day, the former Prime Minister, Mr Bob Hawke, announced that the federal government would nominate the wet tropics as a World Heritage area. This infuriated the Queensland government which then threatened to challenge the Commonwealth in court over the Commonwealth's power to stop logging in the area. However, the state government went to water, and in 1988 899,000 hectares of wet tropical rainforest were inscribed on the World Heritage List. The victory was sweet for all those who had worked so hard on the campaign—they being the real workers, Senator Boswell.

PARA.TAB: On 16 November 1990, the Commonwealth and Queensland governments signed an historic agreement for the management of the wet tropics World Heritage area. The agreement was to establish a ministerial council to coordinate policy and funding at a government-to-government level; to establish a wet tropics management authority to be responsible for achieving the implementation of Australia's obligations under the World Heritage Convention; and to establish a wet tropics management agency to be responsible for the ongoing management of the World Heritage area.

At this point I have to say that four years on there is still not a management plan in place. I think this reflects very poorly on the way in which this government has established World Heritage areas but has not been particularly rapid with the development of management plans. It is not surprising that this has allowed opposition to the idea of World Heritage nomination to grow. We have seen this most recently in the case of the Lake Eyre Basin and the proposed nomination of areas of the Nullarbor Plain.

I make a plea that the government needs to move ahead with the establishment management plans for those areas that have already been inscribed to establish in the public mind the fact that World Heritage does not mean many of the things which have been claimed for it. Many of the scare campaigns which have been run indicate that people have been led to believe that World Heritage necessarily means the cessation of all development, the stopping of everything and no activities whatsoever. This is despite the fact that in the case of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park there is a continuation of many activities which are highly profitable, such as tourism, commercial fishing and recreational fishing. Those activities, provided they are properly managed, are quite compatible with the maintenance of the area as a World Heritage area.

I make the plea at this point that the government moves ahead with the proper and rapid development of management plans for areas like the wet tropics or the Willandra Lakes and at least in outline form for those areas it would wish to have inscribed on the World Heritage List, such as the Nullarbor and Lake Eyre. Only in that way will those fears which many people quite rightly hold be addressed.

Returning to the issue of the wet tropics, Commonwealth funding was provided to the Ravenshoe area to start up alternative employment for those people affected by the prohibition on logging. Senator Boswell will recall that we joined with the opposition in moving a successful motion of no confidence in the then minister over the mismanagement of some of this funding. The former rainforest loggers then began to plant rainforest trees and the bitter disputes between loggers and conservationists that marked that early dispute throughout the mid-1980s have gradually subsided.

I might digress for a moment by saying the lessons of the wet tropics do not appear to have been learnt by this government in relation to other Australian rainforests. Protests are occurring this summer in the World Heritage quality temperate rainforests of Tasmania and in the old growth and wilderness rainforests of East Gippsland, yet the Minister for Resources late last year signed away many areas of old growth forest and wilderness to the woodchip industry. The conflict in the forests will only be removed once the federal government intervenes—as it has done in the past when the political will has been there—to stop logging in old growth forests, ensures their protection and encourages the development of a plantation-based industry. Only in plantation forestry will there be a viable and sustainable future for forestry and timber production in Australia.

I again refer to the Mulgrave Shire where there has been this dramatic shift from an exploitative `cut it down, tear it down, put roads through it' mentality to one in which the shire seeks to maintain the environment and limit the population impact on its environment. I know the chairman of the Mulgrave Shire has embarked on a very exciting program of rainforest plantation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think you have the wrong shire—it's Douglas Shire.

—Sorry; I am talking about Mike Berwick. Could I correct the Hansard record—it should be the Douglas Shire. Under Mike Berwick, the Douglas Shire is engaged in a very exciting program of re-establishing tropical rainforests as plantation timber—something which many people thought could not be done, but which appears now to have been very successfully carried out.

PARA.TAB: Since the inscription of the wet tropics area on the World Heritage List the threat of logging has been replaced by other threats, some of which Senator Reynolds mentioned this afternoon. Not the least of these threats comes from tourism. Very careful management of the area will be needed to ensure that increases in visitation and visitor impact do not have a deleterious impact on the integrity and wilderness beauty of the area.

At this point I would like to point out that while we have often strongly supported the notion of ecotourism and the idea that areas should be protected because in the long run their value in purely economic terms as wilderness areas through tourism far exceeds their value for rapid and destructive exploitation, nonetheless if those values are to be maintained indefinitely one must have an eye on the total visitor impact. Clearly, there is a limit on the number of people one can put into an area and maintain the very values which cause people to be attracted to that area. So I would make a plea that in pushing the case for ecotourism in its advertising, in its attempts to attract visitors from overseas, the government should keep in mind that each of these areas is limited in its ability to absorb tourists and that tourist numbers need to be kept within the ability of the environment to maintain itself.

The issue of the Kuranda skyrail was raised by Senator Reynolds. As I pointed out, the federal minister has not called for an EIS on this skyrail proposal. We have serious reservations about the building of this skyrail because it does involve a commercial development in a national park. I stress that this is a national park in addition to being a World Heritage area. It may be that the total impact on the environment could be reduced by taking people in by skyrail rather than by the buses which now toil up a quite steep escarpment, causing pollution and damage. Somebody said to me just today that Kuranda has essentially become a car park in the midst of a rainforest.

By reducing the amount of road traffic going in there we may well in fact reduce the environmental impact. This needs to be very carefully assessed and so far that assessment has not been done. Moreover, from what I hear from local residents in Kuranda and the local conservation groups, there has been precious little discussion with the affected groups to find out exactly what their views are in relation to this skyrail. A properly conducted environmental impact statement process with public consultation would be a way of achieving that public involvement.

Another issue that has cast a threat over the area is the proposed construction of the Tully-Millstream hydro-electric scheme, something which I think Senator Ian Macdonald mentioned earlier. The state government has apparently shelved the idea for the time being in favour of demand side management, and that is precisely one of the major ways in which the state government should manage its electricity. As I think most honourable senators know, throughout Australia we have tended to build far too many power stations, and it would be possible through proper conservation management to achieve the end purposes of our energy use with the use of much less electricity.

I have also gone into the Burdekin Dam extension. However, the Atherton and Mulgrave shire councils are planning to conduct a poll in the imminent local government elections in which they will put forward a yes case for the hydro-electric scheme. The Cairns Council has decided not to conduct such a poll. However, the Atherton and Mulgrave shire councils claim that 30 other local councils are willing to participate. The poll is nothing but a mischievous action by petty-minded officials who remain trenchantly and irrationally opposed to World Heritage listing. It should be condemned, or at least ignored.

TALK.START.PARA: —What's wrong with a bit of democracy?

—It depends on exactly how the question is put. If a question is put in a biased and leading manner, then certain results will be obtained. Moreover, I think the objective evidence is that further development of hydro-electric power in that area is not this time required. But if at some time in the future the Tully proposal gets back onto the drawing boards at state level, the federal government must use its powers under the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act to stop the dam in the same way as it did in 1983 when the ALP swept to power on the back of its commitment to prevent the damming of the Franklin. One has conflicting values here: one has the World Heritage qualities of this area in conflict with the supposed need for more power.

PARA.TAB: In the words of Dr Len Webb, a tropical ecologist—and I apologise for the sexism in the language; the words are his, not mine:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . in the very near future, the majority of the world's population will live in the tropics. Yet tropical rainforest is the world's most rapidly disappearing resource—like a man dismantling, board by board, the house in which he needs to live. I think the world's rainforests have become a symbol of man's crisis of conscience about his use and abuse of resources.

In order to ensure the greatest possible protection of the wet tropics of Queensland, I call on the government to increase the level of funding for public infrastructure and management programs in the wet tropics. Funding must be increased in recognition of the ever increasing number of tourists visiting the area.

PARA.TAB: In closing, I congratulate the government for bringing this legislation into the parliament. It complements the comprehensive Queensland legislation, the Wet Tropics World Heritage Protection and Management Act 1993. The protection and conservation of this area, which is one of only 11 places in the world that meets all four criteria for World Heritage listing, is an invaluable gift to all the people of the world, both now and in the future.

In conclusion, because of the concern which has been expressed by Senator Reynolds—and I am sure that will be expressed by Senator Chamarette—over the potential threats from development in this World Heritage area, some of which is also national park, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: At the end of the motion, add:

"but the Senate resolves to place on record its firm opposition to any commercial infrastructure development which impacts adversely on the world heritage values of the Wet Tropics World Heritage Area".

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Wet Tropics of Queensland World Heritage Area Conservation Bill furthers the arrangements relating to the wet tropics World Heritage area in Queensland. This bill will give effect to the agreement made between the Commonwealth and the Queensland government on 16 November 1990.

PARA.TAB: The bill will allow the federal minister to nominate two people to be appointed to the board of directors of the Wet Tropics Management Authority in accordance with the Queensland act. It will allow the minister to make arrangements for Australian public servants to work for the authority, and it requires an annual report from the authority on its administration, financial statements and the state of the wet tropic area. That report must be tabled in parliament.

The wet tropic area covers around 900,000 hectares of North Queensland. The management authority is a joint state-federal body set up to manage the wet tropics. The wet tropic area of North Queensland was nominated by the federal Labor government for World Heritage listing in December 1987. Senator Richardson was the then minister for the environment and he banned logging of rainforests in the area. At the same time, the then Prime Minister gave the people of the area an assurance that no person working in the timber industry would be disadvantaged. In April 1988, the Commonwealth government announced a three-year $75 million structural adjustment program, supposedly to assist people and businesses affected by the cessation of logging.

In 1988 when the government introduced its legislation on the wet tropics declaration under World Heritage, I was very concerned about the way the government handled the matter. Sadly, my concerns have been realised. Firstly, 2,000 to 3,000 jobs have been lost in the area, with no prospects of good employment for the people of these timber towns. Mr Hawke may remember his 5 June statement to the timberworkers that `no person working in the timber industry would be disadvantaged', but, as feared by the people at the time, they are very hollow words. At the moment, nearly six years later, the former timberworkers feel sold out, betrayed and forgotten.

What has been left in the wake of the government's inaction to follow through with its assurance is former timber towns filled with great hurt, dislocation and suffering. So I say to Senator Coulter that there are always two sides to an environmental story. There have been some unfortunate consequences of the wet tropic declaration. Sadly, the listing has cost many people in self-sufficient hinterland towns such as Ravenshoe their livelihood and their dignity.

Senator Richardson, when he was the relevant minister, went to the area and made all sorts of promises to the people and businesses which were going to be affected. Ravenshoe has now gone from a self-sufficient town to one with high unemployment. People's lives and businesses have been destroyed. Senator Richardson may have been able to have his career changes from environment minister to disgraced backbencher to resurrected health minister but, unfortunately, the timberworkers, businesses and people of Ravenshoe were deprived of their livelihoods and generations of activities in the timber industry. They did not have the same range of opportunities open to them as Senator Richardson had. To many, their only alternative was the dole. Sadly, what has followed has been marriage breakdowns, nervous breakdowns, health problems, opportunities gone forever and a loss of dignity and despair.

It is the smaller areas that have seen their social and economic fabric destroyed by the heritage listing. I refer to towns like Atherton where the large timber mill which dominated the centre of town remains as a decaying memento of the effect of the government's actions over the wet tropic declaration. Mareeba suffered the same fate. Atherton is a town that could not afford to lose the 200 jobs.

Claims have been made that tourism has increased into northern Queensland. Cairns may be showing the signs of increased activity and all the bustle of progress, but it is the rural communities which once supported the $33 million a year timber industry that have been dealt a death blow. They have gone from viable, economical, self-sufficient communities to dying towns. It has been a high price to pay when we consider the human cost.

The federal government has played a major role in this resulting misery and deprivation of dignity by not sticking to its promises, by letting down people, by being so bureaucratic and pedantic in denying workers and businesses their rightful compensation payments. There were workers who were promised $30,000, but they got only $2,500. Because of a technicality, they missed out on the eligible period of work in the guidelines by a matter of weeks. No number of pleas to minister Kelly could find any compassion in her.

There is a great disappointment in the area with the federal government's handling of the so-called support package. Some feel they were pawns in the government's political needs. Just watching the show Labor in Power showed the Labor Party needed the greenies's vote to win the 1990 election. But the hardworking timber people of the north and the businesses they supported were the ones who had to pay the price for a Labor Party victory. I say to Senator Coulter that I take exception to the fact that he completely disregarded the needs of the working men and women in North Queensland when he said in his contribution that the environmentalists were the hard workers. I do not think that is fair or reasonable.

I will give more examples of the effect of jobs being removed from these local communities. Mr Hawke personally said there would be a loss of only 800 jobs. There always is, and there always has been, a multiplying effect. At least 2,500 jobs have been lost. No community can afford this. There certainly is not a lot of other work available locally. The only jobs available for some of these timberworkers are in far-flung mining areas. Families are separated, with fathers living in one area and mothers staying at home, and this being the only way they could ever get a job. The government could have done more for these people whose lives it entered into, disrupted and, in some cases, destroyed.

Other job creation projects were promised, false claims were being made about tourism. I am very pleased to see the Far North booming and creating jobs and opportunities for all Australians. Tourism is being managed very well in the Far North—22 per cent of all tourists to Australia visit the Far North; Cairns is set to become the second largest cruise ship port; the airport has record numbers of arrivals and there is no doubt that the wet tropic areas form some of that attraction.

But, once again, the communities badly affected by the government's decisions have not been the beneficiaries. There have been projects like the Kirrama tourist resort, the $75 million project at Ravenshoe that would have provided hundreds of jobs. That project just went away because the bureaucracy of the Wet Tropics Management Authority was too slow and too difficult. Projects will not wait around while the authority acts in a slow, cumbersome and bureaucratic way.

Criticism that the bureaucracy is slow has come from no less a source than the Coordinator-General of the Queensland government. As disclosed in a FOI document obtained by the Wilderness Preservation Society, the Coordinator-General said to the Queensland Premier that there had been serious and unreasonable delays to development projects in the Cairns region by the Wet Tropics Management Authority. He further suggested a strategy to speed up the process. The Coordinator-General, in his advice to the Premier, said that projects had been severely hampered by the authority. These are the words of a senior public officer to the Premier of the state.

I believe the Commonwealth government should also take heed of these words from the Queensland Coordinator-General that the authority for which they are jointly responsible is severely hampering projects in the wet tropics region. He specifically criticised as severely hampered projects the $28 million Kuranda skyrail which has just been approved after four years delay, and also the Kirrama resort at Ravenshoe that, in fact, will never go ahead because the investors became sick and tired of the bureaucratic delays of the authority. This was a great blow to Ravenshoe, which has borne the brunt of the government's decision on the wet tropics. This is a town where people have lost their jobs, their investments and values in their homes and businesses.

The compensation package for the loss of logging missed many other losses that continue to this day. There are no reasonable values on homes and businesses in the area which has been denuded of its economic purpose. The authority, with a stroke of its bureaucratic pen, is able to disallow an economic activity which totally devalues any resale of business. In these cases, there is no chance of compensation. There are possibilities in the area which could allow the badly affected areas, such as around Ravenshoe, to re-establish themselves based on tourism. But it will take time, cooperation and a bit of sense from the Wet Tropics Management Authority.

For example, the Kirrama resort project would have guaranteed 100 to 150 permanent jobs. It was a $75 million project which would have returned $11 million each year to the area. But how did the management authority treat the project? Firstly, it would not look at it for over two years. Ninety-five per cent of the road system was already there. It would have used roads that were on the divide of the watershed and would have caused little erosion. It would have opened up five different ecosystems for the public to learn about and admire.

The old timber tracks were there and they could have been opened up as walking tracks with a minimum of damage. It would also have met the requirements of world heritage listing, which is to create access for public appreciation, and that must include all people—not just the super-fit backpackers, but the ordinary bushwalker, the disabled and not so mobile people.

The state government, through the Premiers Department, was providing all the help it could give, but the authority insisted on the alternative route that required crossing a major river, with infrastructure cost to the shire of $7 million. The original route made the area accessible to Ravenshoe and was environmentally non-threatening, using roads that had been in existence since the turn of the century. Needless to say, because of the idealism and years of delay by the authority, the project investors had to pull out and the opportunities for ecotourism and a promised future for Ravenshoe were lost.

It is the same with the Tully Millstream where, because of delays by the authority, the benefits to the Ravenshoe area of drought storage and consequential flood mitigation for Ingham have also been lost. Now that we have the reality of a wet tropics management authority, we must have one that works. As pointed out by the Queensland government when the skyrail project was eventually approved, there is a commitment attached to the World Heritage listing to allow people to see and enjoy our natural wonders, so long as it does not cause damage to the environment.

The projects must go ahead. The authority must manage in a sensible way. There should not be examples, as has happened, of millable logs that are cut for roadworks but that are not allowed to milled and have to be left there or burnt. Electricity authorities must be able to build their powerlines to supplement the power needs of Cairns, Mossman and Port Douglas. The electricity needs of Queensland call for the Tully Millstream to be constructed, contributing 600 megawatts to the electricity grid as well as allowing demand management of supply, which is not possible with the alternatives of coal or diesel.

The authority must look into the real concerns of feral animals in the forests—particularly feral pigs and cats which are growing in numbers. We have to have disease control programs. Money must be spent on real schemes, not mickey mouse tree-planting schemes for residents. Government funded businesses should not be allowed to set up unfairly against private businesses. Fire control must be addressed as a result of the loss of forestry roads.

In the past, the area was managed by the forestry department on a staged basis. It is now a very large area to manage. Money must not be wasted. Tree species planting must be planned with a view to creating a viable future industry, not just short-term rehabilitation. The many projects which have shrivelled up and died because of the excessive bureaucracy of the management authority must be considered in a reasonable amount of time so that these affected regions can remake their futures based on tourism.

The opposition will not be opposing the bill, but I call on the government to ensure that the management authority works for the best interests of the area and its long-term economic future. After all, this is the very least that the government can do as part of its responsibility to the forgotten people of the timber towns who have been left without jobs and opportunities as a result of the government's shabby treatment and its breach of assurances given at the time of the world heritage listing.

We have heard the views of the green or environmentalist lobby expressed by Senator Coulter. My contribution has been made to draw attention to the downside of what has happened to those towns. I can tell Senator Coulter and Senator Chamarette that many people have suffered. They have lost their homes, but worst of all they have lost their self-respect. For three or four generations these people were millworkers, they were timber-getters, and they were proud of their chosen profession. They have now been reduced to painting toilets or collecting the dole. They cannot leave their houses and move away because their houses really have no value.

Those are the things that I want to point out to the people who represent the other side of the debate. There is a very significant downside to the world heritage area. I understand the tourism potential, but that potential was already there and it was working. Those forests have been logged for 80 or 90 years and their conservation appeal was still there after all that time. I put that on the record as the other side of the debate and to show what problems are caused when these areas are declared world heritage areas.

TALK.START.PARA: —As has been stated, the Wet Tropics of Queensland World Heritage Conservation Bill 1993 gives effect to the agreement reached three years ago between the Queensland and federal governments over the management of the wet tropics of Queensland World Heritage area. The bill's stated aim is to facilitate the protection, conservation, presentation and transmission of the area to the future generations. Because the bill merely gives legislative support to the agreement, it says very little about the importance of the area being declared World Heritage. It also says nothing about the need for Aboriginal people being involved in the management of the area.

PARA.TAB: Senator Coulter has already spoken eloquently about the unique environmental qualities of this particular wet tropics World Heritage area, and I will not go into further detail. I feel he has done it justice. I merely want to support everything that he has said. I would also like to underline the question that Senator Coulter raised regarding why the minister for the environment is not requiring an environmental impact assessment for 7.5 kilometres of cableway and for the shops, toilets, kiosk, and an 80-person cafeteria in the middle of the wet tropics world heritage area. I believe this is a question that deserves to be answered by the minister.

On 16 March 1990, when the wet tropics World Heritage area agreement was signed by the then Prime Minister, Bob Hawke, and the Premier of Queensland, Wayne Goss, it was required as a high priority that there be the development of a management plan. After four years, there is none available—not even a draft. The Greens also want to emphasise the necessity that at least a draft management plan should be made available for public input.

Senator Coulter also pointed out the failure of the federal government and the minister for the environment to intervene and protect the valuable high conservation forests of our country, and he was referring to old-growth forests and rainforest areas. I support that concern. We have a problem of national disaster proportions on our hands in Australia in relation to the destruction of old-growth forests. This question must be increasingly raised to challenge the behaviour of the federal government for failing to implement what was, at base, a fairly inadequate national forest policy statement which included a moratorium clause that allowed a moratorium on logging of high conservation value forests.

In saying that, I want to reply to some of the comments made by Senator Boswell regarding the disadvantage and the destructive impact of environmental protection on timberworkers. At this point I do not wish to oppose any of his statements regarding the negative social and employment impacts on people. I believe it is very important that we consider those negative impacts and that we assist the people who are experiencing them.

However, continued logging in old growth forests and rainforest areas disadvantages timber workers. It is not the bans that disadvantage them; it is the fact that logging of old-growth forests occurs at all. It leaves the whole industry unsustainable because it utilises technology and mechanical processes that destroy old-growth forests for woodchipping purposes. This practice gradually diminishes employment opportunities and eventually destroys the industry's base. We need a restructuring of the forest industry before we can satisfactorily address the concerns that Senator Boswell has raised. It is not simply a matter of putting an end to environmental concerns or carrying out environmental assessments; it is a matter of ensuring that environmental impact is considered together with the future impact on people employed in the industry.

Senator Boswell commented on the perceived disadvantages of world heritage listing. The January 1994 edition of the newsletter Wet Tropics Update presented the results of a survey of attitudes towards world heritage areas, and the results are interesting. The survey found that regional support for the listing of wet tropics as a world heritage area has increased from 73 per cent to 80 per cent, and that the incidence of strong support is up from 51 per cent to 59 per cent. Capital city support was relatively steady, up 2 per cent to 72 per cent. Awareness of wet tropics world heritage areas had also increased—in cities, from 31 per cent to 43 per cent, and in regional areas, from 71 per cent to 87 per cent.

I believe that there is an increasing regional awareness of the importance of the wet tropics world heritage area. According to the survey, 57 per cent of North Queenslanders say that the world heritage area is having a positive effect on local communities. Only 16 per cent were reported as perceiving a negative effect. That demonstrates a significant increase in satisfaction with the information provided as well as progress in decision making. More and more people are realising the major benefits of tourism and environmental protection. General support and other positive indicators are highest in Cairns and Townsville, and lower on the tableland and communities south of Cairns.

There is an increasing understanding of the aims of world heritage listing. They are being perceived as being positive measures, designed to protect people living and working in the regions affected, as well as to protect the resources of our wet tropics at world heritage level.

The Cairns and Far North Environment Centre, CAFNEC, has expressed concerns about the management of the wet tropics area by the Wet Tropics Management Authority. I would like to cite some of those concerns because this proposed legislation has failed to take them into account. Some of the problems listed by CAFNEC are: that the decision making is not transparent and that the board takes a behind-closed-doors approach; that management does not adequately take into account regional issues and considerations; that the communities in the region do not feel that they are able to participate; and that the role of the Wet Tropics Management Authority is neither clear nor well understood.

It was also suggested that the authority does not adequately represent or understand the local community and that the present system does not allow politicians to adequately gauge community feeling on issues because there is no forum that allows opposing parties to come together. I suggest that the concerns raised by Senator Boswell are a good example of this. Dialogue that looks at the regional impact of environmental protection is essential if we are to work together in a way beneficial to the regions.

Another comment was that there is too much political interference in the job that the Wet Tropics Management Authority should be doing, and mention was made of the proposed skyrail project. I have already mentioned my concerns regarding that issue but, as Senator Coulter suggested, it will require direct action and intervention to determine whether the project will minimise or exacerbate the impact on this sensitive area. Finally, CAFNEC suggested two changes to this legislation so that, firstly, Ministerial Council meetings would be open to the public and include the chance for the community to arrange representation; and secondly, membership of the Wet Tropics Management Board would be expanded to seven and include non-government representatives resident in Far North Queensland, with at least one coming from the Atherton Tableland.

I intend moving two amendments to this bill to address two distinct problems. The first relates to my concern that the bill at present has no context in which to operate. I foreshadow moving an amendment which would incorporate a preamble to identify the reasons for the bill's introduction and make clear that Aboriginal people have a strong claim for involvement in the management of the wet tropics in Queensland. I understand that the Democrats are moving a similar amendment. At the appropriate time I will suggest that my amendment be moved first because their amendment is similar to mine in part. Secondly, I foreshadow moving a technical amendment which would allow the bill to take into account any changes to the agreement that may occur from time to time consequent to review of the operation of the Wet Tropics of Queensland World Heritage Area Conservation Bill.

I strongly support the amendments moved by the Democrats that would allow Aboriginal people involvement in the management of the wet tropics, and the amendment moved by Senator Coulter, which reflects his concern about commercial infrastructure development impacting adversely on world heritage values. In closing, I stress the importance of the sort of constructive federal involvement that allows regional and local communities to work together in the very important task of protecting world heritage areas.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to thank honourable senators, particularly those from the opposition, for the tenor of this debate. This matter was first raised in this place six years ago and I well remember the angst caused by the decision to list the wet tropics as a world heritage area. This debate shows that we have come to understand the wisdom of that decision. It is nice to know that the opposition is not opposed to the wet tropics of north Queensland being listed as a world heritage area. The wet tropics are one of the great natural phenomena of this country and should be protected forever. It is also nice to know that while some may not see the wisdom of something at the start, wisdom—even that of the opposition—can grow.

PARA.TAB: In the course of the debate, Senator Ian Macdonald asked some questions about funding, and he pointed to what he saw as a discrepancy of $1 million. TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad that Senator Richardson and Senator Crowley are in the chamber because there is a continuing debate in the community about the treatment of two former housekeepers at the Lodge who were retrenched without notice early in October last year. Senator Crowley regularly lectures this chamber on the need to advance the interests of women, which we on this side fully support, and ensure that the power and privilege of government are used in a positive not a negative way.

PARA.TAB: The issue of the two housekeepers at the Lodge is also a matter of widespread community concern. How should the employees of the Prime Minister of this country be treated? Mr and Mrs Keating are entitled to employ whom they wish at the Lodge. What we can insist on is that employees be treated fairly and decently and that their employers do not act in a harsh or capricious manner. At the same time that these housekeepers were retrenched—without notice, I stress—the government was passing through the parliament the so-called Industrial Relations Reform Bill which imposes new obligations on private sector employers. Had Mr Keating been a private sector employer he would not only have been subject to normal common law procedures, but also, under his own act, he would have been subject to new claims for breaches of statutory duties.

It is worth recording just what happened to these two women. On the night of Sunday, 3 October, they received a phone call at home from an officer of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet telling them not to report for duty the following day. Further, these two women were warned that if they tried to attend work the following day and attempted to enter the Lodge they would be turned away by the guards at the gate. They were directed to report to the department on the following Tuesday.

At the department they were apparently given no reasons for their dismissal. They were not even given certificates of service. They were cautioned about the secrecy provisions contained in the Crimes Act and Public Service regulations. Imagine how anyone would feel about this treatment. Imagine how you, Mr Acting Deputy President, would feel. Senator Crowley should imagine how she would feel about being treated in this manner. One of the housekeepers had served two Prime Ministers. The other had been at the Lodge for 12 months and had been made permanent about six months previously.

These sackings were done without any warning. I understand that some days previously the Prime Minister had expressed to one of the housekeepers his satisfaction about the performance of their duties. He had flagged to them that there would be some changes at the Lodge, but that the two housekeepers were assured of employment. Then came the infamous Sunday night telephone call. In my view, the two housekeepers were entitled to be confronted face to face by the relevant officer and given proper reasons why this seemingly harsh action was taken. This did not happen. Instead, there was just a voice on the telephone saying that they were not wanted.

In subsequent days, after numerous requests to the department, they finally received certificates of service from the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. This was three weeks after they had been sacked. The certificates of service state that the two housekeepers provided competent housekeeping services and that their services had been terminated as a result of the staffing arrangements at the Lodge. I seek leave to table the certificates of service of the two housekeepers.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is important to note that the certificate of service states that a certificate of service is not granted to a person if, firstly, a person has been dismissed from service for any offence or misconduct of a serious nature or, secondly, a person has been guilty of frequent acts of misconduct although of a light nature. That is written on the bottom of the certificate of service.

PARA.TAB: Some weeks later, after a response to a question that I asked at the estimates committee regarding staffing at the Lodge, it was revealed by Ms Tinney, a senior officer in the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, that three staff members had been retrenched, including the two housekeepers. In contradiction of the certificates of service which I have cited, it was stated before the estimates committee that the housekeepers failed to carry out directions in relation to the use of their Mastercards.

Ms Tinney said that they were going out and buying things without advising the department. It was alleged that they were apparently not working well together. Finally, it was suggested that they were changing rosters and not completing work that was done on particular rosters. At that time Ms Tinney admitted the housekeepers were not given any warning about their conduct, although she apparently said that changes would have to be made.

The housekeepers have unreservedly denied all allegations of wrongdoing against them. They have sought an explanation as to the reasons for their termination of employment. Senator Gareth Evans compounded the attack on the housekeepers by raising further accusations against them in the Senate; namely, that there were at least four meetings with the staff in which the staff had been asked to improve their working relationships with one another. He also repeated the department's concerns about the credit cards which, it was said, had been drawn to their attention a number of times. These allegations are denied by the housekeepers.

In an attempt to sort out these problems, the coalition attempted to reconvene Estimates Committee A at the end of the last session. Regrettably, this was not supported by the Australian Democrats. The dilemma has always been: how can the housekeepers have the circumstances of their termination of employment dealt with independently when faced with serious allegations by the department? As a result of those allegations they have been out of work. I understand that they are still out of work.

Unless this parliament is prepared to inquire into the matter there are, I understand, no avenues to determine their rights and arrive at a fair and just outcome. The Members of Parliament Act precludes any court action. The statements made by the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet were made under parliamentary privilege and prevent any actions for defamation. The one avenue which seems to offer some hope is for the ombudsman to independently investigate the matter and determine the circumstances of the termination of the housekeepers' employment and the basis for the allegations made by the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet.

I understand from media reports that the ombudsman has agreed to investigate certain matters, but there seems to be some query as to whether the ombudsman has jurisdiction. It is some three weeks after the initial complaints were made to the ombudsman and it is still not clear whether she considers herself to have jurisdiction in a number of areas.

Mr President, I do not want to go into the technical legal arguments. The office of the ombudsman was set up to help protect the private citizen against the oppressive conduct of government. It was also an essential aspect of the ombudsman that this was an avenue of investigation when no other legal remedies were available.

This matter needs to be quickly resolved. I would have thought that all Labor members of parliament believe individual workers are entitled to a fair go. As the saying goes, they are entitled to their day in court. Serious allegations have been made by their employer that have caused them financial loss and personal distress. This is an issue of widespread community concern, as evidenced by the media interest. This issue will not go away until justice prevails and these allegations and counter claims can be independently investigated.

I am delighted that Senator Crowley is in the chamber because she advises the Prime Minister on women's affairs. Although she and I differ on quite a number of issues I hope that with her concern for women and her concern to see justice done she would be prepared to take this matter up and see what can be done to assist these women, to at least give them a chance to have their say and the chance to have the rights and the wrongs of the issue independently determined.

If these matters are not resolved properly and fairly by the ombudsman I ask Senator Woodley, who is in the chamber, to strongly support any motion in his party room so that this parliament could set up an inquiry, whether it be through the estimates process or some other mechanism, to see whether we can assist these two housekeepers to obtain justice.
